  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-program-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="image-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="left banner-image banner-column"><!-- scald=1358:medium_banner --><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/thumbnails/image/030_000008_GSDSTOCK_GundHall_017.jpg?itok=ULspN1JD" width="1400" height="500" alt="Gund Hall" title="Gund Hall" /><!-- END scald=1358 --></div><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>Architecture, Landscape Architecture, and Urban Planning</h1></div></div><div class="banner-text-extension banner-column"></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>PhD degrees in <a href="http://www.gsd.harvard.edu/doctoral-programs/doctor-of-philosophy/">architecture, landscape architecture, and urban planning</a> are administered by a standing committee of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences in cooperation with the Faculty of Design. The program is intended for persons who wish to enter teaching and advanced research careers in the history and theory of architecture, architectural technology, landscape architecture, and urban form from antiquity to the present; or the analysis and development of buildings, cities, landscapes, and regions with an emphasis on social, economic, technological, ecological and infrastructural systems.</p>

<p>The PhD program does not prepare students for licensing as design practitioners in any of these fields or for the doctor of design degree. For information on these programs, please contact the Harvard&nbsp;Graduate School of Design&rsquo;s<a href="http://www.gsd.harvard.edu/admissions/applying-to-the-gsd/index.html">&nbsp;admissions office</a>.</p>

<p>Students in architecture, landscape architecture, and urban planning are enrolled in and receive their degree from the Graduate&nbsp;School of Arts and Sciences, even thought they may&nbsp;work primarily with faculty at the Harvard Graduate School of Design.</p>

<h4>Architectural Technology Track</h4>

<p>PhD students can pursue&nbsp;the architectural technology track, where they can conduct research that aims to advance the state of knowledge in green building, including issues related to computation and simulation, environmental concerns, and energy performance. A background in architecture and or engineering-related fields is required. Students participate in a highly&nbsp;interdisciplinary curriculum that includes theoretical and empirical approaches, especially the history and philosophy of technology, and are associated with the<a href="http://www.harvardcgbc.org/"> Harvard Center for Green Buildings and Cities,</a> which provides intellectual context for student research.</p>

<p>For more information, please contact <a href="mailto:amalkawi@gsd.harvard.edu">Professor Ali Malkawi</a>.</p>

<h2>Admissions Requirements</h2>

<p>Applicants must have completed a four-year bachelor of arts or bachelor of science degree. A professional degree in architecture, landscape architecture, or urban planning is recommended but not required. Students from other countries must demonstrate an excellent command of spoken and written English. To be eligible for admission, applicants must also show evidence of distinguished academic work in the field or closely related fields, or distinguished work in the intended area of concentration. Applications from underrepresented minorities are particularly welcome.</p>

<p>All applicants are required to indicate a proposed major subject of study at the time of initial application. These proposed areas of study should be congruent with the interests and expertise of at least one member of the PhD Standing Committee.</p>

<p>Additional information is available from the <a href="http://www.gsd.harvard.edu/doctorial-programs/doctor-of-philosophy/">PhD Program in Architecture, Landscape Architecture and Urban Planning</a>, and program requirements are available in the <a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/architecture-landscape-architecture-and-urban-planning">GSAS Student Handbook</a>.&nbsp;</p>
</div><h2><div class="label-above" >Theses &amp; Dissertations</div></h2><a href="https://dash.harvard.edu/handle/1/4927603/browse?value=Architecture%2C%20Landscape%20Architecture%20and%20Urban%20Planning&amp;type=department">Theses &amp; Dissertations for Architecture, Landscape Architecture, and Urban Planning</a></div>

<div id="block-ds-extras-program-faculty" class="block block-ds-extras last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Architecture, Landscape Architecture, and Urban Planning Faculty</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-link"><a href="http://www.gsd.harvard.edu/doctorial-programs/doctor-of-philosophy/">See list of Architecture, Landscape Architecture, and Urban Planning faculty</a></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>
                            	</div>
		</div><!-- /#content -->

<meta name="description" content="The Department of Celtic Languages and Literatures at Harvard is the only one of its kind in North America. The department offers training in the languages and traditions of several Celtic languages, and our PhD program requires that students master at least two Celtic languages—Irish and Welsh—in their early (medieval) forms and at least one in its modern form. The program aims to provide PhD candidates with a broad knowledge of the field of Celtic studies, its history, theory, and many diverse branches." />

id="menu-2128-1" class="last even sf-item-4 sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/joint-degrees" class="sf-depth-2">Combined Degrees</a></li></ul></li><li id="menu-1075-1" class="middle even sf-item-2   <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <form action="/student-life/new-students/international-student-faq" method="post" id="search-block-form" accept-charset="UTF-8"><div><div class="container-inline form-wrapper" id="edit-inline"><div class="form-item form-type-textfield form-item-solr-keyword">
 <input type="text" id="edit-solr-keyword" name="solr_keyword" value="" size="60" maxlength="128" class="form-text" />
</div>
<div class="form-actions form-wrapper" id="edit-actions"><input type="submit" id="edit-submit" name="" value="Search" class="form-submit" /></div></div><input type="hidden" name="form_build_id" value="form-Bbbf7hAnI3w6I3fQIkEfNCJ4GiliaPncZBYsqO-TMHI" />

  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-program-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="image-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="left banner-image banner-column"><!-- scald=1450:medium_banner --><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/thumbnails/image/Laws%20of%20Hyel%20Dda_0.jpg?itok=fqNOzCuN" width="1400" height="500" alt="Laws of Hyel Dda page " title="Laws of Hyel Dda page " /><!-- END scald=1450 --></div><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>Celtic Languages and Literatures</h1></div></div><div class="banner-text-extension banner-column"></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>The <a href="http://celtic.fas.harvard.edu/">Department of Celtic Languages and Literatures</a> at Harvard is the only one of its kind in North America. The department offers training in the languages and traditions of several Celtic languages, and our PhD program requires that students master at least two Celtic languages&mdash;Irish and Welsh&mdash;in their early (medieval) forms and at least one in its modern form. The program aims to provide PhD candidates with a broad knowledge of the field of Celtic studies, its history, theory, and many diverse branches. We encourage our students to situate their study of Celtic literatures and oral traditions in the context of the history and material culture of the Celtic-speaking lands. The department is committed to interdisciplinary study and encourages PhD students to do coursework outside the department. Many of our students complete <a href="/programs-study/secondary-fields">Secondary Fields</a> in other departments or programs, such as Medieval Studies or Comparative Literature. The typical time to completion of the PhD in our department is six years.</p>

<p>Our department is small and shares a strong sense of intellectual community. Students work closely with faculty and with one another, not only in courses but in independent Reading and Research modules, advising meetings, informal reading and conversation groups, and the GSAS Celtic Studies Research and Conference Workshop. The annual <a href="http://www.hcc.fas.harvard.edu/index.shtml">Harvard Celtic Colloquium</a>, organized by the third-year PhD students with the assistance of the second-year students and the department administrator and faculty, is a three-day international conference that brings scholars from all over the world to discuss their research in many different branches of Celtic studies. Our program is also enriched by the contribution of speakers in the <a href="http://mahindrahumanities.fas.harvard.edu/content/celtic-literature-and-culture">Mahindra Humanities Center Seminar on Celtic Literatures and Culture</a>.</p>

<h2><strong>Admission Requirements</strong></h2>

<p>The admissions committee assesses every application to the PhD program in Celtic individually and holistically. Students come into the program from different academic backgrounds, including English, History, and Classics, as well as Celtic or Medieval Studies. Some have earned Masters&rsquo; degrees prior to joining the program, and others come directly from their undergraduate studies. In addition to the <a href="/admissions/apply">requirements set by the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences</a>, prospective applicants should take note of the following:</p>

<h2>Writing Sample</h2>

<p>Every application should include a 15&mdash;20-page sample of your academic writing. If you have not done formal work in Celtic studies, the writing sample should draw on your work in any field of literary or historical study. Should you wish to submit a writing sample in Irish, Welsh, or Scottish Gaelic, please include a sample of writing in English as well.&nbsp;</p>

<h2>Languages</h2>

<p>The program requires students to demonstrate the ability to conduct research in Early Irish and Middle Welsh sources, and to achieve reading, speaking and writing competence in Modern Irish, Scottish Gaelic or Welsh. In addition, PhD candidates are required to demonstrate a reading knowledge of Latin, French and German. Because of these fairly extensive language requirements, an applicant with a background in one or more of the requisite languages will have an advantage over the applicant with none.&nbsp;</p>

<h2>Statement of Purpose</h2>

<p>It is not necessary to identify a precise area of specialization at the time of application, and we certainly do not expect incoming students to have defined their dissertation research topic at that point, but it will be helpful for us to have an idea of the questions and interests that you foresee as being fundamental to your graduate work. Your statement of purpose should also describe your background in Celtic studies, the source of your interest in the field, and your sense of how our department is a suitable environment for pursuing your intellectual and professional goals.</p>
</div><h2><div class="label-above" >Theses &amp; Dissertations</div></h2><a href="https://dash.harvard.edu/handle/1/4927603/browse?value=Celtic%20Languages%20and%20Literatures&amp;type=department">Theses &amp; Dissertations for Celtic Languages and Literatures</a></div>

<div id="block-ds-extras-program-faculty" class="block block-ds-extras last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Celtic Languages and Literatures Faculty</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-link"><a href="http://www.celtic.fas.harvard.edu/people.shtml">See list of Celtic Languages and Literatures faculty</a></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>
                            	</div>
		</div><!-- /#content -->

<meta name="description" content="The Department of the Classics has been at the forefront of graduate education in Classics for well over a century. It offers a variety of approaches, emphasizing a wide range of knowledge and skills rather than a narrow early specialization. Traditionally, the PhD in classical philology has been the degree taken by most doctoral candidates, but the department also offers degrees in ancient history, classical archaeology, classical philosophy, Medieval Latin, Byzantine Greek, and Modern Greek." />

  <title>The Classics | Harvard University - The Graduate School of Arts and Sciences</title>

id="menu-2128-1" class="last even sf-item-4 sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/joint-degrees" class="sf-depth-2">Combined Degrees</a></li></ul></li><li id="menu-1075-1" class="middle even sf-item-2   <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <form action="/student-life/new-students/international-student-faq" method="post" id="search-block-form" accept-charset="UTF-8"><div><div class="container-inline form-wrapper" id="edit-inline"><div class="form-item form-type-textfield form-item-solr-keyword">
 <input type="text" id="edit-solr-keyword" name="solr_keyword" value="" size="60" maxlength="128" class="form-text" />
</div>
<div class="form-actions form-wrapper" id="edit-actions"><input type="submit" id="edit-submit" name="" value="Search" class="form-submit" /></div></div><input type="hidden" name="form_build_id" value="form-Bbbf7hAnI3w6I3fQIkEfNCJ4GiliaPncZBYsqO-TMHI" />

  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-program-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="image-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="left banner-image banner-column"><!-- scald=1908:medium_banner --><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/thumbnails/image/8608525%20center%20cropped2.jpg?itok=IvayTy0k" width="1400" height="500" alt="Ancient Coin" title="Ancient Coin" /><!-- END scald=1908 --></div><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>The Classics</h1></div></div><div class="banner-text-extension banner-column"></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>The<a href="http://classics.fas.harvard.edu/graduate"> Department of the Classics</a> has been at the forefront of graduate education in Classics for well over a century. It offers a variety of approaches, emphasizing a wide range of knowledge and skills rather than a narrow early specialization. Traditionally, the PhD in classical philology has been the degree taken by most doctoral candidates, but the department also offers degrees in ancient history, classical archaeology, classical philosophy, Medieval Latin, Byzantine Greek, and Modern Greek. All candidates admitted to the PhD programs are expected to enter with competence in the pertinent languages, ancient and modern, on which they will build in the course of their graduate study.</p>

<p>Though the department views the training of future university teachers as a major part of its mandate, its primary concern is to foster as thorough an expertise as possible in those classical, medieval, and modern fields which are centered on Greek and Latin language and literature. For this reason, the department emphasizes the acquisition not only of knowledge, but also of skills&mdash;in teaching, in analysis, in research&mdash;which will enable its graduates to find careers both within and outside the traditional fields. Great emphasis is laid in the process of graduate admission on the adaptability of students to a flexible job market, and the department assists the career development of its students with placement advice and other practical assistance with the application process.</p>

<p>In working towards a degree in classical philology, students may come to emphasize one language over the other and may explore interests in philology, archaeology, history and prehistory, linguistics, philosophy, religion, law, literary criticism, mythography, or the medieval world both western and eastern. The department also offers specialized training in such disciplines as papyrology, epigraphy, palaeography, and numismatics. The resources of other Harvard departments are open to those interested in other ancient languages and scripts, the history of science, and the relations of the Greeks and the Romans with other ancient cultures.</p>

<p>Ideally, the doctoral program is conceived as lasting six years.</p>

<h2>Admissions Requirements</h2>

<p>When applying online, prospective students must include a recent sample of written work, such as a term paper, senior thesis, or master&rsquo;s essay,&nbsp;ideally&nbsp;15 pages in length.</p>

<p>Visit the Department of the Classics for<a href="http://classics.fas.harvard.edu/graduate"> more information</a> and the GSAS Student Handbook for<a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/classics"> program requirements</a>.</p>

<h3>Doctor of Philosophy in Classical Philology</h3>

<p>Prospective students must have competence in both Greek and Latin sufficient to allow them to take upper-level courses on entering graduate school.</p>

<h3>Doctor of Philosophy in Classical Archaeology</h3>

<p>The field of classical archaeology is understood to cover Aegean, Greek, Etruscan, and Roman art and archaeology. Students may also work on a cross-departmental basis in related fields such as Egyptian, Near Eastern, Anatolian, Punic, Byzantine, and other areas of European art and archaeology.</p>

<p>Entering students are expected to have competence in both Greek and Latin sufficient to take upper-level courses in one of these languages (the &ldquo;major language&rdquo;), and above the beginning level of the other (the &ldquo;minor language&rdquo;). In exceptional circumstances and with the approval of the director of graduate studies, substitution of another ancient language in the place of the minor language may be arranged. Some preparation in German and either French or Italian should be undertaken before admission to the program.</p>

<h3>Doctor of Philosophy in Classical Philosophy</h3>

<p>The purpose of the program in classical philosophy is to provide the student with the basic training in both philosophy and classical philology necessary for work in this field. Students who wish their primary grounding to be in the classics should apply to the program in classical philosophy; those who wish their primary grounding to be in philosophy should apply to the parallel program in the <a href="/programs-of-study/all/philosophy">Department of Philosophy</a>.</p>

<p>Entering students are expected to have competence&nbsp;in Greek and Latin sufficient to&nbsp;take upper-level courses in Greek and above the beginning level in Latin on entering graduate school.</p>

<h3>Doctor of Philosophy in Ancient History</h3>

<p>A bachelor&rsquo;s degree in classics (or one in history combined with substantial study of Greek and Latin) represents the best preparation for the study of ancient history, which is here understood to mean Greek history from the Mycenaean period to Roman times, and Roman history from the beginnings to late antiquity. Students applying to study ancient history in the Department of the Classics must have competence in both Greek and Latin sufficient to take upper-level departmental courses in one of these languages (the &ldquo;major language&rdquo;), and above the beginning level in the other (the &ldquo;minor language&rdquo;). Those wishing to study ancient history at Harvard with less emphasis on languages and texts, and more on other fields of history such as medieval or Byzantine, should note that the <a href="/programs-of-study/all/history">Department of History</a> also offers ancient history as a field in its PhD program.</p>

<p>Some preparation in German and either French or Italian is also advised before admission to the program. In addition, entering students should also have taken the equivalent of two one-term introductory surveys in Greek history and in Roman history.</p>

<h3>Doctor of Philosophy in Medieval Latin</h3>

<p>Prospective students must have competence in both Greek and Latin sufficient to allow them to take upper-level courses on entering graduate school.</p>

<h3>Doctor of Philosophy in Byzantine Greek</h3>

<p>Prospective students must have competence in both Greek and Latin sufficient to allow them to take upper-level courses on entering graduate school.</p>

<h3>Doctor of Philosophy in Modern Greek</h3>

<p>Harvard libraries house some 80,000 volumes in modern Greek language, literature, history, and folklore. The collection dates back to the early 19th century and is the largest and richest in the world outside of Greece. Its uniqueness owes much to Harvard scholars, above all to the efforts of C. C. Felton, E. A. Sophokles, C. Whitman, and A. B. Lord. Areas of outstanding excellence include rare 19th-century periodicals; first editions of major and minor poets and prose-writers of the 19th and 20th centuries; rare printed editions and manuscripts of liturgical and vernacular texts of the 16th to 18th centuries from Venice, Constantinople, Jassy, Bucharest, Jerusalem (many directly related to the rise of the vernacular and to Cretan Renaissance literature); a virtually complete set of first editions of folksong and folklore publications (including periodicals) in Greek, French, Italian, German, and English; the invaluable Whitman/Rinvolucri collection of <em>karagiozes </em>(shadow puppets); and above all the unique and distinctive Parry/Lord and Notopoulos archives of folk music and folk poetry. In addition, Boston libraries (including Boston University) contain largely unresearched materials on the early 19th century Protestant missions to Greece, while the Hellenic College, Brookline, houses an excellent selection of books related to church history.</p>
</div><h2><div class="label-above" >Theses &amp; Dissertations</div></h2><a href="https://dash.harvard.edu/handle/1/4927603/browse?value=Classics&amp;type=department">Theses &amp; Dissertations for The Classics</a></div>

<div id="block-ds-extras-program-faculty" class="block block-ds-extras last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">The Classics Faculty</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-link"><a href="http://classics.fas.harvard.edu/classics-people">See list of The Classics faculty</a></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>
                            	</div>
		</div><!-- /#content -->

<div id="block-block-4" class="block block-block plain last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Contact Us</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <h4>Harvard&nbsp;University</h4>

<h3>Graduate School of Arts &amp; Sciences</h3>

<p>Richard A. and Susan F. Smith Campus Center<br>
1350 Massachusetts Avenue, Suite 350<br>
Cambridge, MA 02138-3654</p>

<p><a class="gmap-icon" href="https://www.google.com/maps/place/1350+Massachusetts+Ave,+Cambridge,+MA+02138/@42.3727139,-71.1210444,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m2!3m1!1s0x89e37742dc1c29a7:0xc3dbda7a42311d03" title="Harvard University - The Graduate School of Arts &amp; Sciences on Google Map">MAP IT</a></p>

<meta name="description" content="Harvard’s Department of Comparative Literature is one of the most dynamic and diverse in the country. With a faculty that has included such scholars as Irving Babbitt, Albert Lord, Harry Levin, Claudio Guillén, and Barbara Johnson, the department has played a crucial role in shaping what remains a polymorphous discipline." />

  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-program-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="image-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="left banner-image banner-column"><!-- scald=1896:medium_banner --><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/thumbnails/image/banner_comparative%203.jpg?itok=Jy_VJ5gK" width="1400" height="500" alt="Comparative Literature Banner" title="Comparative Literature Banner" /><!-- END scald=1896 --></div><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>Comparative Literature</h1></div></div><div class="banner-text-extension banner-column"></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>Harvard&rsquo;s<a href="http://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/graduate"> Department of Comparative Literature</a> is one of the most dynamic and diverse in the country. With a faculty that has included such scholars as Irving Babbitt, Albert Lord, Harry Levin, Claudio Guill&eacute;n, and Barbara Johnson, the department has played a crucial role in shaping what remains a polymorphous discipline. Our 28&nbsp;faculty members and more than 50 graduate students have come from across the globe to study, teach, and publish on literatures in several dozen languages from a wide range of historical periods. The research generated here reflects an exhilarating scope of methods, approaches, and questions. Critical theory, literary interpretation, and comparative philology provide the basis for work on translation, the history of ideas, gender, drama, oral poetics, multilingualism, postcolonialism, the environmental and medical humanities, globalization, and world literature. Our students and faculty also work in a variety of fields contiguous with literature, including architecture and the visual arts, film and music, history, anthropology, philosophy, and medicine.</p>

<p>In our graduate seminars, students analyze in comparative perspective the literatures and other cultural products of Africa, the Americas, Asia, Europe, and the Middle East. Coursework is designed to meet individual interests and expectations. Our students are encouraged to complement seminars in comparative literature with courses in other literature and area studies departments (with which most of our faculty hold joint appointments), including <a href="/programs-of-study/all/african-african-american-studies">African and African American Studies</a>, <a href="/programs-of-study/all/classics">the Classics</a>, <a href="/programs-of-study/all/east-asian-languages-and-civilizations">East Asian Languages and Civilizations</a>, <a href="/programs-of-study/all/english">English</a>,<a href="/programs-of-study/all/germanic-languages-literature"> Germanic Languages and Literatures,</a> <a href="/programs-of-study/all/history">History</a>, <a href="/programs-of-study/all/near-eastern-languages-and-civilizations">Near Eastern Languages and Civilizations</a>, <a href="/programs-of-study/all/romance-languages-and-literatures">Romance Languages and Literatures</a>, <a href="/programs-of-study/all/slavic-languages-and-literatures">Slavic Languages and Literatures</a>, and<a href="/programs-of-study/all/south-asian-studies"> South Asian Studies.</a> Many of our students also engage in interdisciplinary work, taking courses and often earning qualification in secondary fields such as <a href="http://ves.fas.harvard.edu/graduate-program">Film and Visual Studies</a>, <a href="http://medieval.fas.harvard.edu/graduate-program-0">Medieval Studies</a>, <a href="/programs-of-study/all/music">Music</a>, and <a href="http://wgs.fas.harvard.edu/graduate">Studies of Women, Gender, and Sexuality</a>.</p>

<p>The stunning range of our students&rsquo; dissertation projects is well supported by Harvard&rsquo;s unparalleled library resources. Our library system, the largest university collection in the world, comprises 70 libraries, with combined holdings of over 16 million items.</p>

<p>In the past few years, the faculty has restructured the Comparative Literature program so as to attend better to students&rsquo; needs as they prepare for a professional career in the 21st&nbsp;century. New course and language requirements allow students to engage more fully in sophisticated comparative work from their very first year at Harvard. We have also established specific guidelines for advising and faculty feedback from the first year through the completion of the PhD. Our &ldquo;Professing Literature&rdquo; professional development course&nbsp;prepares students for the challenges and opportunities of graduate school. And our Renato Poggioli Faculty/Graduate Student Colloquium&nbsp;enables students of all levels to present their works-in-progress to peers and faculty, everything from seminar papers to mock job talks.</p>

<p>Given the nature of graduate projects, most of our students spend time abroad, both for language training and research. This work is largely funded by fellowships from the graduate school as well as from Harvard&rsquo;s many area centers.</p>

<p>When in Cambridge, students enjoy the department's home, the historic Dana-Palmer House at 16 Quincy Street. With its comfortable lounge and meeting and seminar rooms as well as administrative and faculty offices, Dana-Palmer House provides the perfect setting for scholarly exchange.</p>

<p>The PhD in Comparative Literature generally takes between six and eight years, depending on a student&rsquo;s prior training; most students enter with an AM, but this degree is not required for admission.</p>

<p>Admissions Requirements</p>

<p>The Admissions Committee carefully examines the overall profile of each applicant, taking all parts of the candidate&rsquo;s application into consideration. Locating courses that are offered will help identify which faculty are teaching what courses and if your research interests would be met in our program.&nbsp;Students are also encouraged to closely read faculty websites, which describe the range of expertise of each faculty member.</p>

<p>Your application must include a writing sample, which should demonstrate your ability to engage in literary criticism and/or theory. It can be a paper written for a course or a section of a senior thesis or essay. It is usually between 10 and 20 pages. Do not send longer papers with instructions to read an excerpt; lengthier samples should be edited so that they are no longer than 20&nbsp;pages.</p>

<p>Applicants also need to include a statement of purpose that gives the admissions committee a clear sense of your individual interests and strengths. Candidates for admission need not indicate at the time of application a precise field of specialization, but it is helpful to tell us about your aspirations and how the Department of Comparative Literature might help in attaining these goals. These statements are usually one&nbsp;to four&nbsp;pages long.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/admissions">department's FAQ</a> provide additional information and program requirements are detailed in <em><a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/comparative-literature">The GSAS Student Handbook</a></em>.</p>
</div><h2><div class="label-above" >Theses &amp; Dissertations</div></h2><a href="http://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/phd-dissertations">Theses &amp; Dissertations for Comparative Literature</a></div>

<div id="block-ds-extras-program-faculty" class="block block-ds-extras last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Comparative Literature Faculty</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-faculty"><div  class="ds-2col node node-person view-mode-teaser_2 clearfix">

  
  <div class="group-left">
      </div>

  <div class="group-right">
    <div class="field field-name-title"><a href="/person/verena-conley">Professor Verena Conley</a></div><div class="field field-name-field-professional-title">Director of Graduate Studies</div>  </div>

  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>

              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Contact Us</h2>

      <h4>Harvard&nbsp;University</h4>

<h3>Graduate School of Arts &amp; Sciences</h3>

<p>Richard A. and Susan F. Smith Campus Center<br>
1350 Massachusetts Avenue, Suite 350<br>
Cambridge, MA 02138-3654</p>

  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-program-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="image-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="left banner-image banner-column"><!-- scald=70:medium_banner --><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/thumbnails/image/Korean_royal_palace.JPG?itok=QF5lq4T4" width="1400" height="500" alt="Korean Royal Palace" title="Korean Royal Palace" /><!-- END scald=70 --></div><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>East Asian Languages and Civilizations</h1></div></div><div class="banner-text-extension banner-column"></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>The graduate program in the<a href="http://ealc.fas.harvard.edu/graduate"> Department of East Asian Languages and Civilizations</a> offers the PhD in East Asian Languages and Civilizations&nbsp;in the principal fields of Chinese, Japanese, and Korean literature; Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and Inner Asian history (including Tibet); East Asian Buddhism; and East Asian arts, film, and cultural studies. In addition, the program also offers the <a href="http://ealc.fas.harvard.edu/phd-history-and-east-asian-languages">PhD in history and East Asian languages</a>&nbsp;(HEAL) in Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and Inner Asian history, and in the Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Manchu, Mongolian, and Vietnamese languages; faculty also offer classical (literary) Tibetan in the&nbsp;<a href="https://sas.fas.harvard.edu/tibetan">Department of South Asian Studies</a>.</p>

<p>For those interested in pursuing a master's degree, the&nbsp;Committee on Regional Studies&ndash;East Asia&nbsp;offers an&nbsp;<a href="/programs-of-study/all/regional-studies-east-asia">AM in Regional Studies&ndash;East Asia</a>. More information on the PhD in history with a special field in East Asian history is available from&nbsp;the <a href="http://history.fas.harvard.edu/graduate-programs">Department of History</a>.&nbsp;</p>

<h3>Harvard Resources</h3>

<p><a href="http://fairbank.fas.harvard.edu/">Fairbank Center for Chinese Studies</a><br><a href="http://www.harvardartmuseums.org/">Harvard Art Museums</a><br><a href="http://asiacenter.harvard.edu/">Harvard University Asia Center</a><br><a href="http://www.harvard-yenching.org/">Harvard-Yenching Institute</a><br><a href="http://hcl.harvard.edu/libraries/harvard-yenching/">Harvard-Yenching Library</a><br><a href="http://korea.fas.harvard.edu/">The Korea Institute</a><br><a href="https://www.peabody.harvard.edu/">Peabody Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology</a><br><a href="http://rijs.fas.harvard.edu/">Reischauer Institute of Japanese Studies</a></p>

<h2>Admissions Requirements</h2>

<p>In evaluating applications, faculty consider proven academic excellence, the extent of appropriate language training and prior experience in East Asia, letters of recommendation, writing ability (as demonstrated by a writing sample no longer than 20 pages), and GRE scores, together with the student&rsquo;s own statement of purpose and proposed subject of study. No student can be admitted unless it is felt there is a faculty member who can provide adequate training and supervision.</p>

<p>For those seeking the PhD in East Asian languages and civilizations, the admissions committee gives strong preference&nbsp;to applicants who achieved distinction in their undergraduate or graduate work, and who are adequately prepared to meet the language requirements of the doctorate.&nbsp;The<a href="http://ealc.fas.harvard.edu/phd-history-and-east-asian-languages">&nbsp;PhD in History and East Asian Languages</a>&nbsp;is designed to accommodate the needs of students who desire a more language-intensive program of study of East Asian history. Candidates are expected to have demonstrated special aptitude and competence for advanced work in East Asian history. Admission will be based primarily on distinction in undergraduate or graduate work, including evidence of high achievement in history or related fields, and evidence of adequate preparation in one of the East Asian languages.</p>

<p>Students considering applying to the program may find it beneficial to establish direct contact with faculty prior to applying and are welcome to make a visit to Cambridge to see the campus, its resources, and to meet with faculty.&nbsp;</p>

<p>More information on&nbsp;choosing a PhD program&nbsp;is available from the&nbsp;<a href="https://ealc.fas.harvard.edu/graduate">Department of East Asian Languages and Civilizations</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;the&nbsp;<em>GSAS Student Handbook</em>&nbsp;details EALC&nbsp;<a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/east-asian-languages-and-civilizations">program&nbsp;requirements</a>.</p>
</div><h2><div class="label-above" >Theses &amp; Dissertations</div></h2><a href="https://dash.harvard.edu/handle/1/4927603/browse?value=East%20Asian%20Languages%20and%20Civilizations&amp;type=department">Theses &amp; Dissertations for East Asian Languages and Civilizations</a></div>

<div id="block-ds-extras-program-faculty" class="block block-ds-extras last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">East Asian Languages and Civilizations Faculty</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-link"><a href="https://ealc.fas.harvard.edu/people/taxonomy/term/6536">See list of East Asian Languages and Civilizations faculty</a></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>
                            	</div>
		</div><!-- /#content -->

  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">How to Apply</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-application-deadline-text"><div class="label-above">Special Requirements</div><p>GRE General<br />
Writing Sample</p>
</div><div class="field field-name-field-application-deadline field-type-datetime field-label-above" ><div class="label-above">Application deadline</div><div class="field-item"><span class="date-display-single">December 15, 2017</span></div></div>Deadline 5 p.m. Eastern Time<div class="field field-name-apply-button"><span class="button-large"><a href="/admissions/apply">Apply</a></span></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
<div id="block-ds-extras-program-degrees-offered" class="block block-ds-extras even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Degrees Offered</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field-name-field-degrees-offered"><div>Doctor of Philosophy (PhD)</div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
<div id="block-ds-extras-program-areas-of-study" class="block block-ds-extras plain odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Areas of Study</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <p>Chinese History<br>
Chinese Literature<br>
East Asian Arts/Film/Cultural Studies<br>
History and East Asian Languages<br>
Japanese History<br>
Japanese Literature<br>
Korean History<br>
Korean Literature<br>
Inner Asian<br>
Religion/Philosophy<br>
Tibetan</p>
    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
<div id="block-ds-extras-program-contact-information" class="block block-ds-extras plain last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Contact</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-program-dept-website"><a href="http://ealc.fas.harvard.edu/graduate">East Asian Languages and Civilizations Website</a></div>    </div>
  </div>

	</div>
  </section>

              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Contact Us</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <h4>Harvard&nbsp;University</h4>

<h3>Graduate School of Arts &amp; Sciences</h3>

<p>Richard A. and Susan F. Smith Campus Center<br>
1350 Massachusetts Avenue, Suite 350<br>
Cambridge, MA 02138-3654</p>

<p><a class="gmap-icon" href="https://www.google.com/maps/place/1350+Massachusetts+Ave,+Cambridge,+MA+02138/@42.3727139,-71.1210444,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m2!3m1!1s0x89e37742dc1c29a7:0xc3dbda7a42311d03" title="Harvard University - The Graduate School of Arts &amp; Sciences on Google Map">MAP IT</a></p>

<p><span class="uppercase-label">TEL</span>617-495-5315<br><span class="uppercase-label">FAX</span>617-495-2928<br><span class="uppercase-label">EMAIL</span><a href="mailto:gsas@fas.harvard.edu">gsas@fas.harvard.edu</a></p>

Additional important skills include facility with the tools of scholarship—ancient and modern foreign languages, bibliographic procedures, and textual and editorial methods." />

<div id="block-superfish-1" class="block block-superfish plain even">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <ul id="superfish-1" class="menu sf-menu sf-main-menu sf-horizontal sf-style-none sf-total-items-7 sf-parent-items-7 sf-single-items-0 fouc"><li id="menu-1074-1" class="first odd sf-item-1   <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <form action="/student-life/new-students/international-student-faq" method="post" id="search-block-form" accept-charset="UTF-8"><div><div class="container-inline form-wrapper" id="edit-inline"><div class="form-item form-type-textfield form-item-solr-keyword">
 <input type="text" id="edit-solr-keyword" name="solr_keyword" value="" size="60" maxlength="128" class="form-text" />
</div>
<div class="form-actions form-wrapper" id="edit-actions"><input type="submit" id="edit-submit" name="" value="Search" class="form-submit" /></div></div><input type="hidden" name="form_build_id" value="form-Bbbf7hAnI3w6I3fQIkEfNCJ4GiliaPncZBYsqO-TMHI" />

  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-program-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="image-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="left banner-image banner-column"><!-- scald=72:medium_banner --><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/thumbnails/image/A_Stack_of_Books.png?itok=VFgb_5jp" width="1400" height="500" alt="Wikimedia - Books" title="Wikimedia - Books" /><!-- END scald=72 --></div><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>English</h1></div></div><div class="banner-text-extension banner-column"></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>The<a href="http://english.fas.harvard.edu/graduate/"> Graduate Program in English</a> aims to provide PhD candidates with a broad knowledge of the field of English, including critical and cultural theory. Additional important skills include facility with the tools of scholarship&mdash;ancient and modern foreign languages, bibliographic procedures, and textual and editorial methods. The program also emphasizes the ability to write well, to do solid and innovative scholarly and critical work in a specialized field or fields, to teach effectively, and to make articulate presentations at conferences, seminars, and symposia.</p>

<p>The program takes from four to seven years to complete, with the majority of students finishing in five or six years.</p>

<h2>Admissions Requirements</h2>

<p>&nbsp;The admissions committee carefully examines the overall profile of each applicant, taking all&nbsp;aspects of the application into consideration.<a href="http://english.fas.harvard.edu/graduate/graduate-admissions/"> The English Department FAQs for graduate admissions</a> provide answers to many initial questions and&nbsp;<em>T<a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/english">he GSAS Student Handbook</a> </em>details&nbsp;<a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/english">program requirements</a>.</p>

<h3>Writing Sample</h3>

<p>The writing samples (one primary and one secondary) are highly significant parts of the application. Candidates should submit two double-spaced, 15-page papers of no more than 5,000 words each, in 12-point type with 1-inch margins. The writing samples must be examples of critical writing (rather than creative writing) on subjects directly related to English. Applicants should not send longer papers with instructions to read an excerpt or excerpts, but should edit the samples themselves so that they submit only fifteen pages for each paper. Candidates who know the field in which they expect to specialize should, when possible, submit a primary writing sample related to that field.</p>

<h3>Grades</h3>

<p>While a candidate's&nbsp;overall GPA is important, it is more important to have an average of no lower than A- in literature (and related)&nbsp;courses. In addition, while we encourage applications from candidates in programs other than English, they must have both the requisite critical skills and a foundation in English literature for graduate work in English. Most of our successful candidates have some knowledge of all the major fields of English literary study and advanced knowledge of the field in which they intend to study.</p>

<h3>Three Letters of Recommendation</h3>

<p>It is important to have strong letters of recommendation from professors who are familiar with candidates&rsquo; academic work. Applicants who have been out of school for several years should try to reestablish contact with former professors. Additional letters from employers may also be included. Recommenders should comment not only on the applicant&rsquo;s academic readiness for our PhD program but also on the applicant&rsquo;s future potential as teachers and scholars.</p>

<p>GSAS regrets that applicants cannot use Interfolio or other recommendation dossier services; recommenders must use the GSAS&nbsp;online recommendation system to submit letters of recommendation.</p>

<h3>Graduate Record Examination (GRE)</h3>

<p>High scores in the verbal (at least 166, or 700 in the old scoring system) and subject tests (at least 650 in English Literature) are positive additions to the application, but are by no means the most important aspect of one&rsquo;s candidacy. The quantitative and analytical scores carry less weight than the verbal and subject scores. Applicants should be sure to find out the schedule of <a href="http://www.ets.org/gre">GRE testing</a> in time to have scores sent to Harvard by the end of December. Scores received after the beginning of January may be too late to be considered. &nbsp;The <a href="http://www.ets.org/gre/subject/about/content/literature_english">subject test in English Literature</a> is a paper-based test, only administered three times per year (April, October, and November), so please plan your applications accordingly. The Apply page provides additional information about&nbsp;<a href="/admissions/apply#gre" style="line-height: 24.0001px;">GRE requirements</a>.</p>

<h3>Statement of Purpose</h3>

<p>The Statement of Purpose is not a personal statement and should not be heavily weighted down with autobiographical anecdotes. It should be no longer than 1,000 words. It should give the admissions committee a clear sense of applicants&rsquo; individual interests and strengths. Applicants need not indicate a precise field of specialization, if they do not know, but it is helpful to know something about a candidate&rsquo;s professional aspirations and sense of their own skills, as well as how the Harvard Department of English might help in attaining their goals. Those who already have a research topic in mind should outline it in detail, giving a sense of how they plan their progress through the program. Those who do not should at least attempt to define the questions and interests they foresee driving their work over the next few years.</p>

<h3>Languages</h3>

<p>While there are no specific prerequisites for admission, a strong language background helps to strengthen the application, and students who lack it should be aware that they will need to address these gaps during their first two years of graduate study. More information is <a href="http://english.fas.harvard.edu/graduate/program-description/#LanguageReq">available from the&nbsp;Department of English</a>. &nbsp;</p>
</div><h2><div class="label-above" >Theses &amp; Dissertations</div></h2><a href="https://dash.harvard.edu/handle/1/4927603/browse?value=English&amp;type=department">Theses &amp; Dissertations for English</a></div>

<div id="block-ds-extras-program-faculty" class="block block-ds-extras last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">English Faculty</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-link"><a href="http://english.fas.harvard.edu/people/faculty/">See list of English faculty</a></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>
                            	</div>
		</div><!-- /#content -->

	<div class="region-wrapper">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-program-admissions-info" class="block block-ds-extras first odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">How to Apply</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-application-deadline-text"><div class="label-above">Special Requirements</div><p>GRE General<br />
GRE&nbsp;Subject<br />
Writing Samples</p>
</div><div class="field field-name-field-application-deadline field-type-datetime field-label-above" ><div class="label-above">Application deadline</div><div class="field-item"><span class="date-display-single">January 2, 2018</span></div></div>Deadline 5 p.m. Eastern Time<div class="field field-name-apply-button"><span class="button-large"><a href="/admissions/apply">Apply</a></span></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
<div id="block-ds-extras-program-degrees-offered" class="block block-ds-extras even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Degrees Offered</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field-name-field-degrees-offered"><div>Doctor of Philosophy (PhD)</div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
<div id="block-ds-extras-program-areas-of-study" class="block block-ds-extras plain odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Areas of Study</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <p>Unspecified<br>
Medieval<br>
Renaissance/Early Modern<br>
18th Century/Enlightenment<br>
19th Century British/Romantics/Victorian<br>
Early American (to 1900)<br>
20th Century British<br>
20th Century American<br>
Criticism and Theory<br>
The English Language<br>
Transnational Anglophone/Postcolonial<br>
African American Literature<br>
Drama<br>
Poetry</p>
    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
<div id="block-ds-extras-program-contact-information" class="block block-ds-extras plain last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Contact</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-program-dept-website"><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~english/">English Website</a></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
	</div>
  </section>
          </aside><!-- /.sidebars -->
                
              </div><!-- /#main-content -->
          </div><!-- /.wrapper -->

                <div class="content">

  <div class="block-inner">

                <div class="content">
      <form action="/student-life/new-students/international-student-faq" method="post" id="search-block-form" accept-charset="UTF-8"><div><div class="container-inline form-wrapper" id="edit-inline"><div class="form-item form-type-textfield form-item-solr-keyword">

  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-program-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="image-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="left banner-image banner-column"><!-- scald=73:medium_banner --><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/thumbnails/image/Carpenter_Center-_Harvard_University_-_IMG_0089.JPG?itok=ZijR6ELY" width="1400" height="500" alt="Carpenter Center at Harvard" title="Carpenter Center at Harvard" /><!-- END scald=73 --></div><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>Film and Visual Studies</h1></div></div><div class="banner-text-extension banner-column"></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>The study of film at Harvard functions within the multi-disciplinary examination of audio-visual experience. From Hugo M&uuml;nsterberg&rsquo;s pathbreaking forays into the psychological reception of moving images and Rudolf Arnheim&rsquo;s seminal investigations of &ldquo;visual thinking&rdquo; to Paul Sachs&rsquo;s incorporation of film into the academic and curatorial focus of the fine arts at Harvard&nbsp;and Stanley Cavell&rsquo;s philosophical approaches to the medium, Harvard has sustained a distinguished tradition of engaging cinema and the cultural, visual, spatial, and philosophical questions that it raises. With their emphases on experimentation in the contemporary arts and creative collaboration among practitioners and critics, the <a href="http://ves.fas.harvard.edu">Department of Visual and Environmental Studies</a> and the <a href="http://ccva.fas.harvard.edu">Carpenter Center for the Visual Arts</a> provide a singular and unparalleled site for advanced research in <a href="http://ves.fas.harvard.edu/graduate-program">Film and Visual Studies</a>. The program aims to foster critical understanding of the interactions between the making of and thinking about film and video, between studio art, performance, and visual culture, and between different arts and pursuits whose objects are audio-visual entities. The Carpenter Center also supports a lively research culture, including the Film and Visual Studies Colloquium and a Film and Visual Studies Workshop for advanced doctoral students, as well as lecture series and exhibitions featuring distinguished artists, filmmakers, and scholars.</p>

<p>Interdisciplinary in its impetus, the program draws on and consolidates course offerings in departments throughout the Faculty of Arts and Sciences which consider film and the spatial arts in all their various countenances and investigate the place of visual arts within a variety of contexts. Graduate students may also take advantage of the significant resources of the <a href="http://hcl.harvard.edu/hfa/">Harvard Film Archive</a>,&nbsp;which houses a vast collection of 16mm and 35mm film prints as well as rare video materials, vintage film posters, photographs, and promotional materials. The Harvard Film Archive&nbsp;furthers the artistic and academic appreciation of moving image media within the Harvard and the New England community, offering a setting where students and faculty can interact with filmmakers and artists. The archive&nbsp;also houses a <a href="http://library.harvard.edu/preservation/media-preservation-film">Film Conservation Center</a> that allows the archive's&nbsp;conservator and staff to accession new films as well as to preserve its significant collections of independent, international, and silent films.</p>

<p>Students and faculty in Film and Visual Studies are also eligible to apply to the <a href="http://www.filmstudycenter.org/">Film Study Center</a> for fellowships&nbsp;awarded annually in support of original film, video, and photographic projects. Established in 1957, the Film Study Center provides production equipment, post-production facilities, technical support, and funding for nonfiction works that interpret the world through images and sounds. Among the many important films to have been produced at the Film Study Center are John Marshall&rsquo;s <em>The Hunters&nbsp;</em>(1956), Robert Gardner&rsquo;s <em>Forest of Bliss</em> (1985), Irene Lusztig&rsquo;s <em>Reconstruction&nbsp;</em>(2001), Robb Moss&rsquo;s <em>The Same River Twice</em> (2002), and, most recently, Ross McElwee&rsquo;s <em>Bright Leaves</em> (2003), Peter Galison and Robb Moss&rsquo;s <em>Secrecy</em> (2008), Ilisa Barbash and Lucien Castaing-Taylor&rsquo;s <em>Sweetgrass </em>(2009), J. P. Sniadecki and V&eacute;r&eacute;na Paravel&rsquo;s <em>Foreign Parts</em> (2011), Lucien Castaing-Taylor and V&eacute;r&eacute;na Paravel&rsquo;s <em>Leviathan </em>(2013), and Stephanie Spray and Pacho Velez&rsquo;s <em>Manakamana</em> (2014).</p>

<p><a href="http://ves.fas.harvard.edu/graduate-program">More information on graduate study</a> is&nbsp;available from&nbsp;Film and Visual Studies and the<em> GSAS Student Handbook</em> details <a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/film-and-visual-studies">program requirements</a>.</p>

<h2>Admissions Requirements</h2>

<p>The following is a set of general guidelines for the admissions process. It should be noted that while several areas are emphasized here, the admissions committee will carefully examine the overall profile of each applicant, taking these and other aspects of the candidate&rsquo;s application into consideration.</p>

<h4>The Writing Sample</h4>

<p>The writing sample is one of the most important materials in the application. Candidates should submit only one 15&ndash;20 page paper, in 12-point type, double-spaced throughout,&nbsp;with normal margins. The writing sample must be an example of critical writing (rather than creative writing) on a subject directly related to film, performance and/or visual studies. You should not send longer papers with instructions to read an excerpt or excerpts; edit the sample so that you submit only up to 20 pages.</p>

<h4>Grades</h4>

<p>While the overall GPA is important, it is more important to have an average of no lower than A- in courses related to film and visual studies or related fields. In addition, if you have not majored in film studies or a related field, it is important to have sufficient background to enter the graduate program&mdash;a matter perhaps best determined by speaking with your undergraduate advisor.</p>

<h4>Letters of Recommendation</h4>

<p>It is important to have three strong letters of recommendation from professors who are familiar with your academic work. If you have been out of school for several years, reestablish contact with former professors. Additional letters from employers may also be included.</p>

<h4>GREs</h4>

<p>High scores&nbsp;(170)&nbsp;&nbsp;in the verbal portion of the test&nbsp;are positive additions to the application but are by no means the most important aspect of your candidacy.&nbsp;(The quantitative and analytical scores carry less weight than the verbal scores.) You should make timely plans to take these examinations in order to ensure arrival of scores by the December early application deadline. Scores received after January may arrive too late to be considered.</p>

<h4>Statement of Purpose</h4>

<p>The statement of purpose should give the admissions committee a clear sense of your individual interests and strengths. You don&rsquo;t need to indicate at the time of application precisely what your field of specialization will be, but it is helpful to know something about your aspirations, and how Film and Visual Studies at Harvard might help in attaining these goals.</p>

<h4>Languages</h4>

<p>Strong language background helps to strengthen the application, and students who lack it should be aware that they will need to repair these gaps during their first two years of graduate study.</p>
</div><h2><div class="label-above" >Theses &amp; Dissertations</div></h2><a href="https://dash.harvard.edu/handle/1/4927603/browse?value=Film%20and%20Visual%20Studies&amp;type=department">Theses &amp; Dissertations for Film and Visual Studies</a></div>

<div id="block-ds-extras-program-faculty" class="block block-ds-extras last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Film and Visual Studies Faculty</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-link"><a href="http://ves.fas.harvard.edu/people/people-category/faculty">See list of Film and Visual Studies faculty</a></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>
                            	</div>
		</div><!-- /#content -->

Writing Sample</p>

<meta name="description" content="A major strength of the graduate program in Germanic Languages and Literatures is its flexibility. While the main focus is on German literature and cultural studies, students often include comparative literature, art, philosophy, film studies, history, and history of science in their coursework and dissertation. Under the guidance of the director of graduate studies, students develop a plan of study that aims, on the one hand, for broad general knowledge of the field as a whole and, on the other, for special emphases of their own." />

                          <h1 id="site-name">
                <a href="/" title="Home" rel="home"><span>Harvard University - The Graduate School of Arts and Sciences</span></a>

<div id="block-views-programs-of-studay-block-1" class="block block-views audience-jump-menu plain last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Info for</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="view view-programs-of-studay view-id-programs_of_studay view-display-id-block_1 view-dom-id-51a2a95b7f6da52f4a17fbfcea7a9331">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">

  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-program-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="image-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="left banner-image banner-column"><!-- scald=74:medium_banner --><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/thumbnails/image/The_German_classics_of_the_nineteenth_and_twentieth_centuries%3B_masterpieces_of_German_literature_%281913%29_%2814770586724%29.jpg?itok=87i7VF9a" width="1400" height="500" alt="German classics of 19th and 20th century" title="German classics of 19th and 20th century" /><!-- END scald=74 --></div><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>Germanic Languages and Literatures</h1></div></div><div class="banner-text-extension banner-column"></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>A major strength of the<a href="http://german.fas.harvard.edu/graduate"> graduate program in Germanic Languages and Literatures</a> is its flexibility. While the main focus is on German literature and cultural studies, students often include comparative literature, art, philosophy, film studies, history, and history of science in their coursework and dissertation. Under the guidance of the director of graduate studies, students develop a plan of study that aims, on the one hand, for broad general knowledge of the field as a whole and, on the other, for special emphases of their own. Often, dissertation topics emerge from seminar papers; in addition, preparation for the PhD general exam is specifically geared toward developing expertise in a period and a genre.</p>

<p>We also offer older Germanic languages, notably Old Norse, as well as courses on specific aspects of the medieval period. A doctoral program in the older languages is available, which&nbsp;draws on resources in related disciplines such as English and medieval history. &nbsp;</p>

<p>Teaching is required for the PhD degree, not only because sound training and practice are essential for a career in higher education, but also because it provides transferable skills in many other careers for which a PhD may be helpful. Graduate students normally begin teaching in their third year of study. New teachers take a course in foreign language pedagogy, and all graduate students involved in language teaching profit from the guidance of the language program coordinator. Opportunities are provided to teach elementary and intermediate language classes, where the graduate student is responsible for the entire weekly instruction of a class. Many of our graduate students assist in high-enrollment courses on literature, film, thought, and culture given by members of the department or professors in related departments; in such courses, the graduate student leads a weekly discussion group under the direction of the course head. Graduate students may also participate as teaching fellows in the undergraduate Program in General Education, again as leaders of small-group discussion sections that accompany lectures given by a professor. Our students have benefited not only from the teaching opportunities these courses offer, but also from General Education seminars, a special category of course in which they participate in developing the syllabus and materials for a General Education course and receive training in skills needed for teaching undergraduates who are not necessarily specializing in the field.</p>

<p>The department conducts regular professional development workshops designed to help graduate students prepare to apply for positions, polish their interviewing skills, practice giving a talk in connection with a job application, and create other materials useful in the job search.</p>

<p>We also have a regular workshop for dissertation&nbsp;writers and a colloquium where graduate students at all levels share their work. Every two years, our graduate students design and organize a conference on a topic of their choice; beyond developing organizational skills, this conference allows our students to engage with graduate students at other universities and to get to know more closely the distinguished scholar who gives the keynote speech. Our program has special connections with the Humboldt University in Berlin: every year, several students from the Humboldt come to do research here and participate in our dissertation-writers&rsquo; workshop; students from our own cohort may also choose to spend time studying at the Humboldt in Berlin.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The rich resources that Harvard offers scholars in Germanic studies include Widener Library&rsquo;s holdings, which many consider the best German studies research collection in North America; Houghton Library, with its collection of medieval manuscripts and the papers of such major German poets as Hofmannsthal, Rilke, Brecht, and Heine, as well as annotated typescripts of W. G. Sebald&rsquo;s prose works; the map room in Pusey Library is a revelation; and the Harvard Film Archive, whose collection of 35- and 16-millimeter German films, videos, press booklets, and photographs is unique.</p>

<h2>Admissions Requirements</h2>

<p>All prospective students are required to submit with their online application a copy of a term paper or essay written dealing with a topic in German literature or a closely related field.</p>

<p>More information is available from the <a href="http://german.fas.harvard.edu/graduate">Department of Germanic Languages and Literatures</a> and the&nbsp;<em>GSAS Student Handbook</em> details<a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/germanic-languages-and-literatures">&nbsp;program </a>requirements.</p>
</div><h2><div class="label-above" >Theses &amp; Dissertations</div></h2><a href="https://dash.harvard.edu/handle/1/4927603/browse?value=Germanic%20Languages%20and%20Literatures&amp;type=department">Theses &amp; Dissertations for Germanic Languages and Literatures</a></div>

<div id="block-ds-extras-program-faculty" class="block block-ds-extras last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Germanic Languages and Literatures Faculty</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-link"><a href="http://german.fas.harvard.edu/terms-people/faculty">See list of Germanic Languages and Literatures faculty</a></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>
                            	</div>
		</div><!-- /#content -->

Throughout the program, students work with advisors and other faculty members as they engage in coursework, prepare for and take the general exam, work as teaching fellows, and research and write the dissertation. It generally takes students six or seven years to finish their doctoral degree." />

<body class="html not-front not-logged-in one-sidebar sidebar-second page-node page-node- page-node-50 node-type-program section-programs-of-study" >

      <div id="page" class="clearfix">
  <header id="header" role="banner">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="header-content">
                  <a href="/" title="Home" rel="home" id="logo"><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/all/themes/gsas/logo.png" alt="Harvard University - The Graduate School of Arts and Sciences" id="bitmap-logo" /><img src="/sites/all/themes/gsas/logo.svg" id="svg-logo" alt="Harvard University - The Graduate School of Arts and Sciences" /></a>
                          <hgroup id="name-and-slogan">
                          <h1 id="site-name">
                <a href="/" title="Home" rel="home"><span>Harvard University - The Graduate School of Arts and Sciences</span></a>
              </h1>
            
                      </hgroup><!-- /#name-and-slogan -->
                
          <div class="header__region region region-header">
    <div id="block-superfish-2" class="block block-superfish plain first odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">

  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <form action="/student-life/new-students/international-student-faq" method="post" id="search-block-form" accept-charset="UTF-8"><div><div class="container-inline form-wrapper" id="edit-inline"><div class="form-item form-type-textfield form-item-solr-keyword">
