  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-program-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="image-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="left banner-image banner-column"><!-- scald=77:medium_banner --><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/thumbnails/image/Robinson_Hall_%28Harvard_University%29_-_DSC00069.JPG?itok=YJBHQMF_" width="1400" height="500" alt="Robinson Hall at Harvard" title="Robinson Hall at Harvard" /><!-- END scald=77 --></div><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>History</h1></div></div><div class="banner-text-extension banner-column"></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>The<a href="http://history.fas.harvard.edu/graduate-programs"> PhD program in history</a>&nbsp;trains students to become both skilled scholars and conscientious teachers. Throughout the program, students work with advisors and other faculty members as they engage in coursework, prepare for and take the general exam, work as teaching fellows, and research and write the dissertation. It generally takes students six or seven years to finish their doctoral degree. Most graduates have pursued academic careers at universities and colleges in the United States and abroad, while others have gone on to successful careers in law and in government.</p>

<p>The department has over 50 faculty members with a wide range of research specialties, spanning chronologically from ancient to 20th-century history, geographically from Asia to the United States, and thematically from intellectual history to global and transnational history. Their world-class scholarship garners awards, fellowships, and acclaim, strengthening the recognition of our department as a powerhouse of historical scholarship. Many of our faculty members share appointments with other departments and schools on campus and are involved in interdisciplinary collaborations with committees, programs, and institutions both at Harvard and around the world.</p>

<p>As a large research university, Harvard offers many resources and opportunities for its students in the form of lectures, conferences, research centers, fellowships, and grants. Students have access to the more than 80 libraries and 17 million volumes that comprise the Harvard Library, the largest university library in the world.</p>

<p>Additionally, students may take courses offered by other departments in the Faculty of Arts and Sciences, or at other Harvard schools, such as Harvard Divinity School, Harvard Law School, Harvard Graduate School of Education, and Harvard Kennedy School.</p>

<p>In coordination with Harvard Law School, students may pursue both a PhD in history and a JD at Harvard Law School. To learn more about this course of study consult the<a href="http://hls.harvard.edu/dept/academics/degree-programs/special-programs/coordinated-jdphd-program/"> Coordinated JD/PhD program</a> overview.</p>

<p>Admissions Requirements</p>

<p>Each year, the department ordinarily receives between 300 and 400 applications to the doctoral program and offers admission to about 6 percent of applicants. The typical incoming class size is 16 students. The admissions process is extremely competitive, but if you are serious about pursuing a PhD in history, you are encouraged to apply.</p>

<p>Successful applications have shared many of the following characteristics:</p>

<ul><li>Personal statement that makes clear why the applicant wants to study history in graduate school, and why the applicant wants to study at Harvard. This statement often illustrates the applicant&rsquo;s research interests and notes potential advisors</li>
	<li>Three strong letters of reference from people who know the applicant&rsquo;s writing</li>
	<li>Writing sample of remarkable quality that asks historical questions</li>
	<li>Fluent or nearly fluent in English</li>
	<li>Reading ability in two languages other than English</li>
	<li>Strong undergraduate, and, if applicable, graduate record, with excellent marks in history courses</li>
	<li>High GRE scores</li>
</ul><p>GRE General Test&nbsp;</p>

<p>Prospective candidates must submit scores for the <a href="http://www.ets.org/gre/revised_general/about">GRE General Test</a> by the application deadline. The Apply page provides additional information about <a href="/admissions/apply#gre">GRE requirements</a>.</p>

<p>Answers to&nbsp;<a href="http://history.fas.harvard.edu/frequently-asked-questions-faq">frequently asked questions</a> about the admissions process are available from the Department of History&nbsp;and the&nbsp;<em>GSAS Student Handbook</em> for <a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/history">program requirements</a>.</p>
</div><h2><div class="label-above" >Theses &amp; Dissertations</div></h2><a href="https://dash.harvard.edu/handle/1/4927603/browse?value=History&amp;type=department">Theses &amp; Dissertations for History</a></div>

<div id="block-ds-extras-program-faculty" class="block block-ds-extras last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">History Faculty</h2>

  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>

<body class="html not-front not-logged-in one-sidebar sidebar-second page-node page-node- page-node-47 node-type-program section-programs-of-study" >

      <a href="#main-menu" class="element-invisible element-focusable">Jump to navigation</a>
    </p>
      <div id="page" class="clearfix">
  <header id="header" role="banner">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="header-content">
                  <a href="/" title="Home" rel="home" id="logo"><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/all/themes/gsas/logo.png" alt="Harvard University - The Graduate School of Arts and Sciences" id="bitmap-logo" /><img src="/sites/all/themes/gsas/logo.svg" id="svg-logo" alt="Harvard University - The Graduate School of Arts and Sciences" /></a>
                          <hgroup id="name-and-slogan">
                          <h1 id="site-name">
                <a href="/" title="Home" rel="home"><span>Harvard University - The Graduate School of Arts and Sciences</span></a>
              </h1>
            
                      </hgroup><!-- /#name-and-slogan -->
                
          <div class="header__region region region-header">
    <div id="block-superfish-2" class="block block-superfish plain first odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">

  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <form action="/student-life/new-students/international-student-faq" method="post" id="search-block-form" accept-charset="UTF-8"><div><div class="container-inline form-wrapper" id="edit-inline"><div class="form-item form-type-textfield form-item-solr-keyword">
 <input type="text" id="edit-solr-keyword" name="solr_keyword" value="" size="60" maxlength="128" class="form-text" />
</div>
<div class="form-actions form-wrapper" id="edit-actions"><input type="submit" id="edit-submit" name="" value="Search" class="form-submit" /></div></div><input type="hidden" name="form_build_id" value="form-Bbbf7hAnI3w6I3fQIkEfNCJ4GiliaPncZBYsqO-TMHI" />

  </div><!-- /#navigation -->
  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-program-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="image-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="left banner-image banner-column"><!-- scald=78:medium_banner --><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/thumbnails/image/Fogg_Art_Museum%2C_Harvard_University.jpg?itok=4hdz-9LN" width="1400" height="500" alt="Harvard Art Museum" title="Harvard Art Museum" /><!-- END scald=78 --></div><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>History of Art and Architecture</h1></div></div><div class="banner-text-extension banner-column"></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>The graduate program in the<a href="http://haa.fas.harvard.edu/admissionsprospective-students"> Department of History of Art and Architecture</a>&nbsp;offers a program of instruction that prepares students for teaching the history and theory of art at the college level, for museum work, and for independent research and writing. The department offers instruction in the following broad fields of the history of art and architecture:</p>

<ul><li>African</li>
	<li>Greek and Roman</li>
	<li>East Asian</li>
	<li>Islamic</li>
	<li>Latin American</li>
	<li>Medieval/Byzantine</li>
	<li>Modern (nineteenth and twentieth centuries)</li>
	<li>Renaissance and Baroque (fifteenth through eighteenth centuries)</li>
	<li>South Asian</li>
</ul><p>The graduate curriculum is designed to ensure breadth across the discipline, both in terms of field distribution and methodology.</p>

<p>The department regularly invites authorities from other universities and museums to offer instruction in Cambridge, and the M. Victor Leventritt Lecture brings outstanding authorities to the campus each year for lectures and meetings with students and faculty.&nbsp;The many colleges, museums, and commercial galleries in the greater Boston area provide a stimulating environment for study and research.</p>

<p>Collections of Western, Asian, and ethnographic art housed in Harvard&rsquo;s museums enrich student training by providing fine original works of art for study. The Straus Center for Conservation and Technical Studies offers instruction in the history of techniques and materials. Harvard&rsquo;s library holdings include more than 200,000 books on art and archaeology, more than 800,000 photographs and slides, and an extensive collection of rare books and manuscripts. Finally, students of history of art and architecture are encouraged to take full advantage of the University&rsquo;s course offerings in the humanities and social sciences and the rich intellectual and cultural life of the campus at large.</p>

<p>No studio art is offered by the department.</p>

<h2>Admissions Requirements</h2>

<p>While there are no specific prerequisites for admission, a strong language background helps to strengthen the application, and students who lack it should be aware that they will need to address these gaps during their first two years of graduate study.</p>

<p>Applicants must include a recent sample of written work with their online application.</p>

<p><a href="http://haa.fas.harvard.edu/admissionsprospective-students" style="line-height: 1.71429em;">More information</a> is available from Department of History of Art and Architecture and the <em>GSAS Student Handbook </em>details <a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/history-art-and-architecture" style="line-height: 1.71429em;">program requirements</a>.</p>
</div><h2><div class="label-above" >Theses &amp; Dissertations</div></h2><a href="https://dash.harvard.edu/handle/1/4927603/browse?value=History%20of%20Art%20and%20Architecture&amp;type=department">Theses &amp; Dissertations for History of Art and Architecture</a></div>

<div id="block-ds-extras-program-faculty" class="block block-ds-extras last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">History of Art and Architecture Faculty</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-link"><a href="http://haa.fas.harvard.edu/people/taxonomy/term/9391">See list of History of Art and Architecture faculty</a></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>

      <div id="page" class="clearfix">
  <header id="header" role="banner">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="header-content">
                  <a href="/" title="Home" rel="home" id="logo"><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/all/themes/gsas/logo.png" alt="Harvard University - The Graduate School of Arts and Sciences" id="bitmap-logo" /><img src="/sites/all/themes/gsas/logo.svg" id="svg-logo" alt="Harvard University - The Graduate School of Arts and Sciences" /></a>
                          <hgroup id="name-and-slogan">
                          <h1 id="site-name">
                <a href="/" title="Home" rel="home"><span>Harvard University - The Graduate School of Arts and Sciences</span></a>
              </h1>
            
                      </hgroup><!-- /#name-and-slogan -->
                
          <div class="header__region region region-header">
    <div id="block-superfish-2" class="block block-superfish plain first odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">

  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <form action="/student-life/new-students/international-student-faq" method="post" id="search-block-form" accept-charset="UTF-8"><div><div class="container-inline form-wrapper" id="edit-inline"><div class="form-item form-type-textfield form-item-solr-keyword">
 <input type="text" id="edit-solr-keyword" name="solr_keyword" value="" size="60" maxlength="128" class="form-text" />
</div>
<div class="form-actions form-wrapper" id="edit-actions"><input type="submit" id="edit-submit" name="" value="Search" class="form-submit" /></div></div><input type="hidden" name="form_build_id" value="form-Bbbf7hAnI3w6I3fQIkEfNCJ4GiliaPncZBYsqO-TMHI" />

  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-program-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="gray-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>History of Science</h1></div></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>The<a href="http://histsci.fas.harvard.edu/academics/graduate-program"> Department of the History of Science</a> offers a comprehensive graduate program leading to the AM and PhD degrees. We are one of the world&rsquo;s leading institutions for producing the next generation of professional historians of science, training students to examine the development of science through a course of study that lays a broad foundation for teaching and research across the field. Our faculty and students employ historical, textual, ethnographic, and social scientific methods to explore the genesis and evolution of the sciences and to analyze the growth of science as part of the intellectual and social experience of humankind, as well as to ask larger questions about how the various sciences work in practice and the basis of their authority, how ethical and political decisions are made about their regulation and applications, how they relate to larger intellectual, cultural, social, and political trends and changes, and much more. Faculty and student interests span medieval to contemporary times, and engage the full range of sciences: physics, astronomy, molecular biology, evolutionary theory, technology, brain and behavioral science, the psychological sciences, medicine, and public health. Together we form a lively interdisciplinary community of scholars.</p>

<p>Graduate students select courses in history of science and history as well as in fields such as&nbsp;philosophy, government, literature, sociology, anthropology, law, and public policy. Courses in the<a href="http://web.mit.edu/sts/"> Program on Science, Technology, and Society</a> at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology may be taken by cross-registration, as may courses in<a href="http://belfercenter.ksg.harvard.edu/project/44/science_technology_and_public_policy.html?page_id=24"> Science, Technology, and Policy</a> at the Harvard Kennedy School. PhD students may also choose to pursue a <a href="/programs-study/secondary-fields">secondary field</a> such as&nbsp;critical media practice; studies of women, gender, and sexuality; film and visual studies; or&nbsp;science, technology, and society.</p>

<p>Our students are encouraged to engage with the department&rsquo;s<a href="http://chsi.harvard.edu/"> Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments</a>, which is one of the largest and richest university collections in the world. These objects represent a broad range of periods and scientific disciplines, including astronomy, navigation, horology, surveying, geology, calculating, physics, biology, medicine, psychology, electricity, and communication. Many departmental courses have a component that uses the collections&nbsp;and students may participate in the curating&nbsp;of special exhibitions; several of our recent PhD graduates have gone on to careers in museum work.</p>

<p>Our programs are exciting and intellectually demanding, and our graduate student community is stimulating and diverse. We welcome international students, and in recent years have admitted applicants from many countries, including Taiwan, China, Great Britain, India, Romania, Israel, Germany, Mexico, and Canada.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Master of Arts (AM)</p>

<p>The department offers admission to a very few select students seeking the free-standing AM degree. External applicants for the degree may be considered on a case-by-case basis; it is expected they will be in fulltime residence. Students who have been accepted to pursue an AM include those pursuing a PhD in another Harvard department, advanced degree candidates at foreign universities, and students with a PhD in another field, from Harvard or elsewhere.</p>

<p>Admissions Requirements</p>

<p>To pursue advanced work in the field, it is desirable to have some preliminary training in the natural or social sciences and in history.&nbsp;No application to the Department of the History of Science will be considered complete unless accompanied by a sample of the student&rsquo;s recent written work (e.g., term paper, senior thesis, master&rsquo;s essay). Writing samples should be uploaded when completing the online application.</p>

<p>While our faculty invite prospective students to contact them with questions about graduate study in the department, it is not necessary to visit the department to apply for admission to the graduate program. We are not set up to accommodate formal visits from prospective students, but can, on a limited basis, accommodate requests from applicants for brief meetings with faculty with whom they are interested in working. If you will be in the Boston area, please contact individual faculty members well in advance.</p>

<p>More information is available from the&nbsp;<a href="http://histsci.fas.harvard.edu/academics/graduate-program">Department of the History of Science</a>, including&nbsp;&nbsp;videos of faculty and students. Access the <em>GSAS Student Handbook</em> to learn more about <a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/history-science">program requirements</a> for the MA&nbsp;and PhD degrees.</p>

<p>Historical Theses and Dissertations</p>

<p><a href="http://histsci.fas.harvard.edu/files/hos/files/phd_theses_in_history_of_science_by_year_1941_through_2015_created_12_17_15.pdf">List of History of Science&nbsp;Dissertations and&nbsp;Doctoral Graduates, 1941 to&nbsp;2015</a></p>
</div><h2><div class="label-above" >Theses &amp; Dissertations</div></h2><a href="https://dash.harvard.edu/handle/1/4927603/browse?value=History%20of%20Science&amp;type=department">Theses &amp; Dissertations for History of Science</a></div>

<div id="block-ds-extras-program-faculty" class="block block-ds-extras last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">History of Science Faculty</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-link"><a href="http://histsci.fas.harvard.edu/people/faculty">See list of History of Science faculty</a></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>

<meta name="description" content="Inner Asian and Altaic Studies focuses on the history and cultures of the peoples in the steppe, mountain, forest, and oasis areas between China, Russia, western Iran, and Pakistan. This geographic area comprises Central Asia (namely former Soviet Central Asia, Xinjiang, eastern Iran, and Afghanistan), Kazakhstan, the northern regions of Pakistan, Tibet (including Qinghai, eastern Sichuan, Gansu, and northwestern Yunnan), Mongolia, and Manchuria. The Altaic languages include the Turkic group, the Mongolian group, and the Tunguzic group." />

<body class="html not-front not-logged-in one-sidebar sidebar-second page-node page-node- page-node-62 node-type-program section-programs-of-study" >
      <p id="skip-link">
      <a href="#main-menu" class="element-invisible element-focusable">Jump to navigation</a>
    </p>
      <div id="page" class="clearfix">

                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="image-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="left banner-image banner-column"><!-- scald=80:medium_banner --><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/thumbnails/image/Tajik_Wedding_Rituals._Chimilig_WDL2514_0.png?itok=BInE61jz" width="1400" height="500" alt="Tajik Wedding Rituals" title="Tajik Wedding Rituals" /><!-- END scald=80 --></div><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>Inner Asian and Altaic Studies</h1></div></div><div class="banner-text-extension banner-column"></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>Inner Asian and Altaic Studies&#8239;focuses on the history and cultures of the peoples in the steppe, mountain, forest, and oasis areas between China, Russia, western Iran, and Pakistan. This geographic area comprises Central Asia (namely former Soviet Central Asia, Xinjiang, eastern Iran, and Afghanistan), Kazakhstan, the northern regions of Pakistan, Tibet (including Qinghai, eastern Sichuan, Gansu, and northwestern Yunnan), Mongolia, and Manchuria. The Altaic languages include the Turkic group, the Mongolian group, and the Tunguzic group.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://iaas.fas.harvard.edu/" style="text-decoration:none;">Committee on Inner Asian and Altaic Studies</a> supervises the work of graduate students whose interest in Inner Asia is not confined to languages or history alone, but encompasses linguistics, history, religion, art history, and general cultural study. Courses relating to Inner Asian studies are given by members of the committee and other faculty in the departments of anthropology, East Asian languages and civilizations, history, history of art and architecture, linguistics, music, Near Eastern languages and civilizations, South Asian studies (formerly the Department of Sanskrit and Indian Studies), and by the Committee on the Study of Religion. &nbsp;</p>

<p>Harvard is preeminent among the very few universities where Inner Asian and Altaic studies may be pursued. Harvard&rsquo;s library holdings in East European, East Asian, Islamic, and South Asian areas led to a development of strength in the Inner Asian and Altaic fields prior to the actual establishment of this program. The research centers and degree programs that exist at Harvard on the four sides of the Inner Asian area have contributed much material directly relevant to the study of this region. Among its vast holdings,&#8239;Harvard possesses outstanding collections in many languages including those of Arabic, Chinese, Indian, Iranian, Russian, Tibetan, and Turkish, which comprise the most important primary sources for the study of this area.&#8239;These collections can be found in the Widener, Harvard-Yenching, Houghton, Dumbarton Oaks, Gibb, Tozzer, Fung, and Fine Arts libraries.&#8239;</p>

<h2>Admissions Requirements</h2>

<p>All students in the program are expected to meet the requirements of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, including a bachelor&rsquo;s degree from a recognized institution, a superior undergraduate record, and reading knowledge of at least one appropriate foreign source language such as, for example, Arabic, Chinese, Manchu, Persian, Russian, or Turkish. A master&rsquo;s degree in hand is advantageous. &nbsp;</p>

<p>Candidates must submit a recent writing sample, preferably on a topic relevant to their application.&#8239;</p>

<p>More information&nbsp;is available from the&nbsp;<a href="http://iaas.fas.harvard.edu/">Committee on Inner Asian and Altaic Studies</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/inner-asian-and-altaic-studies" style="line-height: 24.0001px;">program requirements</a>&nbsp;for the degree are detailed&nbsp;in the&nbsp;<em>GSAS Student Handbook</em>.</p>
</div></div>

<div id="block-ds-extras-program-faculty" class="block block-ds-extras last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Inner Asian and Altaic Studies Faculty</h2>

      <div class="field field-name-field-link"><a href="http://iaas.fas.harvard.edu/pages/iaas-committee-members">See list of Inner Asian and Altaic Studies faculty</a></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>

		</div><!-- /#content -->

Harvard began offering higher degrees in “comparative philology,” as historical linguistics was then called, as early as the 1930s. By 1941, Harvard had a full-fledged Department of Comparative Philology, which became the Department of Linguistics a decade later." />

<body class="html not-front not-logged-in one-sidebar sidebar-second page-node page-node- page-node-63 node-type-program section-programs-of-study" >
      <p id="skip-link">
      <a href="#main-menu" class="element-invisible element-focusable">Jump to navigation</a>
    </p>
      <div id="page" class="clearfix">
  <header id="header" role="banner">
    <div class="wrapper">

          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>The <a href="http://linguistics.fas.harvard.edu/pages/graduate">Department of Linguistics</a> is home to one of the oldest and most distinguished linguistics programs in the United States. Harvard began offering higher degrees in &ldquo;comparative philology,&rdquo; as historical linguistics was then called, as early as the 1930s. By 1941, Harvard had a full-fledged Department of Comparative Philology, which became the Department of Linguistics a decade later.</p>

<p>The department experienced rapid growth in the 1960s, with the advent of transformational-generative grammar. We became the first linguistics department in the Ivy League to organize its program along generative lines, while also maintaining our traditional strength in historical linguistics.</p>

<p>Now, as then, the department fosters a culture of unity in diversity. Our students and faculty come from many different backgrounds and represent a wide range of interests, from purely theoretical to typological, historical, and experimental. What we share is a commitment to empirically grounded research and a respect for the rich traditions of the field.</p>

<p>The study of linguistics at Harvard draws much of its strength from the unique range and depth of the University's offerings in related fields, especially ancient and modern languages and the growing <a href="http://mbb.harvard.edu/">Mind/Brain/Behavior Initiative</a>. Students are encouraged to take advantage of the full spectrum of Harvard's resources in planning their schedules; they are also free to cross-register for linguistics and linguistics-related courses at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. While all PhD candidates are expected to acquire a solid background in contemporary linguistic theory, the department places great emphasis on the inseparability of good theoretical work and detailed empirical research, and on the interrelatedness of diachronic and synchronic approaches to the study of linguistic phenomena.</p>

<p>Since the department is relatively small, discussion among faculty, graduate students, and undergraduates is ongoing and informal. Special workshops funded by the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, together with frequent departmentally sponsored lectures and seminars, bring an unusually large number of outside speakers to Harvard every year. Widener Library contains a matchless linguistic and philological collection, supplemented by a special non-circulating collection accessible only to linguistics students and faculty.</p>

<h2>Admissions Requirements</h2>

<p>Requirements for admission are flexible. Preference is normally given to candidates with a previous background in linguistics, but students with a mature interest in the field and a strong language background are encouraged to apply as well. GRE scores are required of all applicants, and are valid if taken within the last five years.</p>

<p>More information is available from the <a href="http://linguistics.fas.harvard.edu/pages/graduate">Department of Linguistics</a> and <em>The GSAS Student Handbook</em>&nbsp;details&nbsp;<a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/linguistics">program requirements</a>.</p>
</div><h2><div class="label-above" >Theses &amp; Dissertations</div></h2><a href="https://dash.harvard.edu/handle/1/4927603/browse?value=Linguistics&amp;type=department">Theses &amp; Dissertations for Linguistics</a></div>

<div id="block-ds-extras-program-faculty" class="block block-ds-extras last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Linguistics Faculty</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-link"><a href="http://linguistics.fas.harvard.edu/people/faculty">See list of Linguistics faculty</a></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>
                            	</div>
		</div><!-- /#content -->

<body class="html not-front not-logged-in one-sidebar sidebar-second page-node page-node- page-node-64 node-type-program section-programs-of-study" >

      <a href="#main-menu" class="element-invisible element-focusable">Jump to navigation</a>
    </p>
      <div id="page" class="clearfix">
  <header id="header" role="banner">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="header-content">
                  <a href="/" title="Home" rel="home" id="logo"><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/all/themes/gsas/logo.png" alt="Harvard University - The Graduate School of Arts and Sciences" id="bitmap-logo" /><img src="/sites/all/themes/gsas/logo.svg" id="svg-logo" alt="Harvard University - The Graduate School of Arts and Sciences" /></a>
                          <hgroup id="name-and-slogan">
                          <h1 id="site-name">
                <a href="/" title="Home" rel="home"><span>Harvard University - The Graduate School of Arts and Sciences</span></a>
              </h1>
            
                      </hgroup><!-- /#name-and-slogan -->
                
          <div class="header__region region region-header">
    <div id="block-superfish-2" class="block block-superfish plain first odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">

  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-program-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="image-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="left banner-image banner-column"><!-- scald=81:medium_banner --><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/thumbnails/image/090407_Features_KS_007.jpg?itok=6JMz3YAY" width="1400" height="500" alt="Middle Eastern Studies" title="Middle Eastern Studies" /><!-- END scald=81 --></div><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>Middle Eastern Studies</h1></div></div><div class="banner-text-extension banner-column"></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>Harvard&rsquo;s graduate programs in<a href="http://cmes.fas.harvard.edu/academic-programs"> Middle Eastern studies</a> are coordinated by the<a href="http://cmes.fas.harvard.edu/home"> Center for Middle Eastern Studies</a> (CMES). Established in 1954 to support research and teaching on the Middle East, CMES has produced generations of scholars with a profound understanding of and active engagement in the region. At the core of the Center&rsquo;s mandate is the pursuit of firsthand knowledge about the Middle East based on literacy in its languages and a deep understanding of its diverse politics, cultures, and histories.</p>

<p>Taking a broad interdisciplinary approach encompassing the humanities and social sciences as well as the arts and natural sciences, CMES engages with faculty from across Harvard University whose teaching and research focus on the Middle East, and with other regional studies centers and Harvard libraries and museums holding exceptional and unparalleled collections related to Middle Eastern and Islamic studies. This dynamic academic community includes over 40 faculty, a diverse cohort of more than 50 graduate students, and an annual contingent of 12 to 15 visiting researchers.</p>

<h2>Degree Programs</h2>

<p>CMES offers a master&rsquo;s degree in Regional Studies&mdash;Middle East and three joint doctoral degrees with the departments of anthropology, history, and the history of art and architecture.</p>

<h3>AM Program in Regional Studies&mdash;Middle East</h3>

<p>The master&rsquo;s degree in Middle Eastern studies (AM) is a rigorous two-year academic program designed for entrepreneurial students who wish to develop new academic interests or pursue professional skills. Students have diverse profiles and come from the United States and around the world. They share a capacity for rigorous, scholarly exploration of the Middle East region in all its richness and complexity.</p>

<p>Graduates of the program pursue careers in diplomacy, business, media, human rights, and non-governmental work. Some continue for further graduate study in law school, medical school, or PhD programs.</p>

<p>Master&rsquo;s students make valuable contributions to the intellectual community at CMES, their academic home while in the program, and are encouraged to participate in a range of CMES activities, programs, and workshops.</p>

<h3>PhD Programs</h3>

<p>Students of the joint PhD programs complete both the requirements of the related department and the language and area studies requirements established by CMES. In addition to coursework and comprehensive exams, PhD students develop a high proficiency in at least one Middle Eastern language and complete a dissertation based on original research.</p>

<h4>Joint PhD in Anthropology and Middle Eastern Studies</h4>

<p>The joint program in anthropology and Middle Eastern Studies is designed for students interested in enriching their program of study for the PhD in anthropology with firsthand knowledge about the Middle East based on literacy in its languages and an understanding of its cultural traditions. Students are full members of the Department of Anthropology cohort, but also have an intellectual home at CMES and access to CMES faculty, facilities, and resources.</p>

<h4>Joint PhD in History and Middle Eastern Studies</h4>

<p>The joint program in History and Middle Eastern Studies is designed for students interested in enriching their program of study for the PhD in History with firsthand knowledge about the Middle East based on literacy in its languages and an understanding of its history. Students are full members of the Department of History cohort, but also have an intellectual home at CMES and access to CMES faculty, facilities, and resources.</p>

<h4>Joint PhD in History of Art and Architecture and Middle Eastern Studies</h4>

<p>The joint program in History of Art and Architecture and Middle Eastern Studies is designed for students interested in enriching their program of study for the PhD in History of Art and Architecture with firsthand knowledge about the Middle East based on literacy in its artistic traditions. Students are full members of the Department of History of Art and Architecture cohort, but also have an intellectual home at CMES and access to CMES faculty, facilities, and resources.</p>

<h2>Admissions Requirements</h2>

<p>CMES welcomes applications from students with a demonstrated interest in Middle Eastern studies. Strong recommendations and a compelling statement of purpose are vital to a successful application. The GRE is required of all applicants; however there is no minimum score or minimum GPA. The admissions committee takes into consideration all elements of an applicant&rsquo;s background in their evaluation of applications. Prior language training in a Middle Eastern language is not a prerequisite, although it is advantageous to one&rsquo;s application.</p>

<p>Prospective students should read the program descriptions (<a href="http://cmes.fas.harvard.edu/am-program">AM</a> and<a href="http://cmes.fas.harvard.edu/phd-programs"> PhD</a>) carefully before submitting their applications. Students should also consult the CMES<a href="http://cmes.fas.harvard.edu/applying/faqs"> Prospective Student FAQs</a> for answers to common questions about applying to CMES.</p>

<p>&nbsp;<em>The GSAS Student Handbook</em> provides more information&nbsp;about <a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/middle-eastern-studies">program requirements</a>.</p>
</div><h2><div class="label-above" >Theses &amp; Dissertations</div></h2><a href="https://dash.harvard.edu/handle/1/4927603/browse?value=Middle%20Eastern%20Studies%20Committee&amp;type=department">Theses &amp; Dissertations for Middle Eastern Studies</a></div>

<div id="block-ds-extras-program-faculty" class="block block-ds-extras last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Middle Eastern Studies Faculty</h2>

      <div class="field field-name-field-link"><a href="http://cmes.fas.harvard.edu/people/faculty">See list of Middle Eastern Studies faculty</a></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>

  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="image-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="left banner-image banner-column"><!-- scald=82:medium_banner --><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/thumbnails/image/020315_Iyer_Vijay_130.jpg?itok=4PmEm0P3" width="1400" height="500" alt="Vijay Iyer" title="Vijay Iyer" /><!-- END scald=82 --></div><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>Music</h1></div></div><div class="banner-text-extension banner-column"></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>The<a href="https://music.fas.harvard.edu/graduate.shtml">&nbsp;graduate program of the Department of Music</a> offers advanced training in&nbsp; historical musicology, ethnomusicology, theory, and composition, leading to the degree of PhD in Music. There is no admission to an AM program separate from these PhD programs. In unusual cases, students who cannot successfully complete the general examination may be given the option of completing the requirements for a terminal AM degree.</p>

<p>At any given time, 55 to 70 graduate students are in residence, and between 6 and 12 new graduate students enter each year. The Music Building contains a concert hall (the John Knowles Paine Concert Hall), classrooms, faculty and graduate offices, a superb research library (the Eda Kuhn Loeb Music Library), a microfilm library of primary source materials (the Isham Memorial Library), an archive of world music recordings, listening facilities, a high-quality electronic music studio (HUSEAC: Harvard University Studio for Electroacoustic Composition), an ethnomusicology lab, a collection of early instruments, chamber music rehearsal rooms, and individual piano practice rooms. Other facilities throughout Harvard University include the vast resources of Widener Library, the Houghton Library (which contains rare music prints and manuscripts, and autographs of major composers), Lamont Media, and the library and practice rooms of Dudley House (the center of graduate student activities). In addition, a wealth of musical opportunities is readily available to Harvard students at many neighboring universities (e.g., Boston University, Berklee&nbsp;College of Music, Brandeis University, M.I.T, and the New England Conservatory) and civic and professional institutions (e.g., Boston Symphony Orchestra, Boston Public Library, and Museum of Fine Arts with the Mason Collection of Musical Instruments).</p>

<p>Graduate students are awarded six years guaranteed funding (including living expenses) when accepted to a PhD program.</p>

<h2>Programs and Degrees</h2>

<h3>The Program in Musicology and Ethnomusicology</h3>

<p>At Harvard, musicology is broadly defined as the disciplined study of music and includes the historical, comparative, and systematic aspects of the field. The program incorporates two tracks: historical musicology, with an emphasis on the history, theory, and literature of Western music in its contexts from antiquity to the present; and ethnomusicology, which concentrates on the ethnographic study of any musical tradition in relationship to its cultural setting. Most graduate courses in historical musicology and ethnomusicology are research seminars; many treat specific topics, periods, and regions, while others deal with current problems and methods. On the completion of preparatory training and the passing of the general examinations, PhD dissertations may be written in either field.</p>

<h3>The Program in Theory</h3>

<p>The PhD in music theory is characterized both by a deep involvement in the inner workings of music and by an engagement with the wider philosophical, cultural, and psychological questions surrounding music. The program reflects this interdisciplinary interest of our students&nbsp;and seeks to explore the links of music theory to other areas of critical engagement, while providing our theorists with the specialized skills they require.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The teaching in the program emphasizes analytical techniques&mdash;all students take courses on Schenkerian theory and on a range of tonal and post-tonal analytical practices, as well as an introductory course to explore current issues in the field. At the same time, the program also encourages students to build a framework in which to place these techniques and to reflect on the underpinnings of music theory. Regular courses on questions in psychology, temporality, history of music theory, and aesthetics are also available and often take music theory into interdisciplinary territory. Graduate courses on challenging repertoires&mdash;e.g. modal theory, non-Western music, or very recent composition&mdash;frequently round off our offerings.</p>

<p>The dissertation projects our theory graduates work on reflect this unique combination of interests. Recent and current PhD topics include feminist approaches to performance analysis, microtonality and tone imaginations, multi-modal analysis of boy-band videos, Athanasius Kircher's <em>Musurgia&nbsp;Universalis</em> (1650), and neuro-scientific imaging of perceptual parameters.</p>

<p>Our theory faculty is enhanced on a regular basis by exciting visiting faculty, who complement our existing research and teaching strengths in interesting new ways. Recent visitors have included Allan Keiler (Brandeis), Fred Lerdahl (Columbia), Allen Forte (Yale), Ellie Hisama (Columbia), and Martin Scherzinger (NYU), as well as Brian Ferneyhough (Stanford), Helmut Lachenmann (Stuttgart), and Harrison Birtwistle (London).&nbsp;</p>

<h3>The Program in Composition</h3>

<p>Harvard's program in composition is designed to give students the time and opportunity to develop as composers by offering general musical guidance as well as specific individual criticism of their works. The program is centered around the students' achieving clarity of expression through developing their command of compositional technique. In addition, acquaintance with the literature of the past and present through analysis and performance is considered indispensable. Most courses are seminars and deal with specific topics or student works.</p>

<p>The student typically spends the first two years in the department on coursework. The third, fourth, and fifth years are devoted to work on the dissertation and teaching, as well as active participation in composition colloquia and Harvard Group for New Music concerts. Composers may spend one term during their 4th year at another art institution or university if a particular research project or artistic residency can be obtained.</p>

<p>On the completion of preparatory training and the passing of the general examinations (during the summer before the third year), PhD dissertations comprising a substantial portfolio of between five and seven pieces of varied scoring and length may be submitted.&nbsp;</p>

<h3>AM&nbsp;in Performance Practice</h3>

<p><strong>* Applications are not being accepted for fall 2018&nbsp;</strong></p>

<p>The AM&nbsp;in music with a specialty in performance practice&nbsp;is designed to provide intellectual and scholarly background to finished musicians who are preparing or engaged in careers as performers and teachers. The emphasis is on preparing students to work with sources, editions, theoretical writings, organology, and other matters of importance to performance styles as related to repertories. Additional areas such as differences in the meaning of terminology and notation from composer to composer or from era to era,&nbsp;ornamentatio, liberties of tempo and declamation, and improvisation will be addressed. It is a two-year program in which students take a selection of departmental courses focused on this specialty and write an AM&nbsp;thesis.</p>

<h3>Cross-Disciplinary Research</h3>

<p>Many innovative research areas are not classifiable along traditional lines but rather borrow from a variety of approaches and methods. This includes projects that integrate creative components or performance into academic work. Candidates interested in the cross-disciplinary category should clearly lay out their academic interests and musical experience. They should present a clear rationale for the cross-disciplinary nature of their interests. Where appropriate, candidates are encouraged to include performance materials in their application.&nbsp;Candidates admitted through the cross-disciplinary category will declare one of the departmental programs and&nbsp;will take generals and pursue dissertation work in that program, with modifications as appropriate.</p>

<h2>Admissions Requirements</h2>

<p>Admissions decisions are made by Department of Music faculty, who weigh a combination of factors such as GRE scores, past academic record, strength of scholarly (or compositional) work, and recommendations. The TOEFL test may be required if English is not your first language (recommended minimum score is 80). All applicants are required to take the GRE general test.</p>

<p><a href="https://music.fas.harvard.edu/prospectivegrad.shtml">More information</a> is available&nbsp;the Department of Music and <em>The GSAS Student Handbook&nbsp;</em>details&nbsp;<a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/music">program requirements</a>.</p>

<h3>Samples of previous work</h3>

<p>Applicants to the all programs except the composition PhD must submit, along with their applications, samples of their previous scholarly work in musicology (for the musicology PhD), ethnomusicology (for ethnomusicology PhD), or theory (for the theory PhD). The online application will allow you to upload up to 20 pages of material.</p>

<p>Applicants to the composition PhD must submit three to four compositions. Scores are required in printed format and should be mailed to the GSAS Office of Admissions (scores will not be returned unless a self-addressed, stamped envelope is included). Recordings are highly recommended; links to SoundCloud or other online resource should be noted in the Additional Academic Background section of the application.</p>

<h3>Requirements for the&nbsp;AM in Performance Practice</h3>

<p><strong>* Applications are not being accepted for fall 2018</strong></p>

<p>Ordinarily, the department expects to enroll one to two AM&nbsp;students a year or every two years. No auditions are required.&nbsp;<br><br>
Financial Aid for this program is very limited. Students may apply for Paine Traveling Fellowships and/or the Department Travel Fund to support some of their research. All fellowship funding is at the discretion of the Scholarship Committee. Other University funding may be available.<br><br>
NOTE: Students wishing to continue at Harvard for the PhD will apply in the normal manner and their applications will be considered in the customary way. Students admitted to the PhD program will be granted credit for work done at Harvard or elsewhere according to departmental guidelines.</p>

<h3>Visiting the Department</h3>

<p>You are welcome to visit the Department of Music at any time, although we in no way require or expect you to make the trip. You should know that we do invite the students we admit to our program to come to Cambridge as part of our admissions process. At that time, admitted students meet with faculty, get to know our current students, and are introduced to other students who have also been admitted.</p>

<p><em>We regret that we are not able to make appointments with individual faculty members during a pre-admissions visit.</em></p>

<p>If you do decide to make a visit prior to the admissions deadline, there are optimal times to visit, such as between October and our December holiday break. If you visit at another time of the year, check the academic schedule to avoid reading/exam periods and semester breaks. <em>It is not necessary to visit, nor should you see it as a way to improve your chances of admission.</em></p>

<p>Rather, a visit is simply a good way to learn about our department's intellectual environment and infrastructure. We urge you to consult the<a href="https://music.fas.harvard.edu/courseschedule.shtml"> course schedule</a> so that you can plan to sit in on one or more graduate seminars (please <a href="mailto:musicdpt@fas.harvard.edu">e-mail the department</a> to ask permission of the instructing professor first). This is the best way to get to know the professors and students.&nbsp;You may also want to attend any<a href="https://music.fas.harvard.edu/calendar.shtml"> colloquia, lectures, or faculty seminars</a> that coincide with your visit or make an appointment to tour the music library and other Harvard libraries. It may also be possible to chat informally with some of our current graduate students, who are apt to be working in the department and library during the academic year.</p>

<p>Contact&nbsp;<a href="mailto:%20denny2@fas.harvard.edu">Kaye Denny</a> or <a href="mailto:stillman@fas.harvard.edu">Charles Stillman</a> or call 617-495-2791 for&nbsp;more information about the schedule of events.</p>
</div><h2><div class="label-above" >Theses &amp; Dissertations</div></h2><a href="https://dash.harvard.edu/handle/1/4927603/browse?value=Music&amp;type=department">Theses &amp; Dissertations for Music</a></div>

</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>

Music Theory&nbsp;(PhD only)<br>
Musicology/Ethnomusicology&nbsp;(PhD only)<br>
Musicology/Historical&nbsp;(PhD only)<br>
Performance Practice* (AM only)</p>

<p>* Applications for Performance Practice AM are not being accepted for fall 2018&nbsp;</p>

                <div class="content">
      <form action="/student-life/new-students/international-student-faq" method="post" id="search-block-form" accept-charset="UTF-8"><div><div class="container-inline form-wrapper" id="edit-inline"><div class="form-item form-type-textfield form-item-solr-keyword">

</div>
<div class="form-actions form-wrapper" id="edit-actions"><input type="submit" id="edit-submit" name="" value="Search" class="form-submit" /></div></div><input type="hidden" name="form_build_id" value="form-Bbbf7hAnI3w6I3fQIkEfNCJ4GiliaPncZBYsqO-TMHI" />

  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-program-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="image-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="left banner-image banner-column"><!-- scald=83:medium_banner --><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/thumbnails/image/slider_jerusalemtower.jpg?itok=Q0BW394y" width="1400" height="500" alt="Jerusalem Tower" title="Jerusalem Tower" /><!-- END scald=83 --></div><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>Near Eastern Languages and Civilizations</h1></div></div><div class="banner-text-extension banner-column"></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>The<a href="http://www.nelc.fas.harvard.edu/"> Department of Near Eastern Languages and Civilizations</a> (NELC) encompasses the study of ancient and modern peoples, languages, literatures, cultures, and societies of the Near and Middle East. Languages include Akkadian, Arabic, Aramaic, Armenian, Babylonian, Egyptian, Hebrew, Iranian, Persian, Sumerian, Turkish, and Yiddish.</p>

<p>The NELC faculty is world-renowned and Harvard&rsquo;s educational resources in the various fields of Near Eastern studies are virtually unparalleled.<a href="http://hcl.harvard.edu/libraries/widener/"> Widener Library</a>, for example, has a broad assortment of holdings in Arabic, Armenian, Hebrew, Persian, Turkish, and Yiddish literature. For students interested in biblical or other ancient Near Eastern studies, or in the archaeology of the Near East, a variety of opportunities for archaeological work in the Middle East are available. Students interested in the modern Near Eastern political or social studies should familiarize themselves with the resources and personnel of the<a href="https://cmes.fas.harvard.edu/"> Center for Middle Eastern Studies</a> (CMES). CMES is the coordinating body and a primary source of intellectual and material support within Harvard for scholarly pursuits covering the vast area between Morocco and Iran, and beyond. It was the first center of its kind and is responsible for teaching as well as research. The <a href="https://cjs.fas.harvard.edu/">Center for Jewish Studies</a> (CJS) is the focal point at Harvard for the study and teaching of Judaica through publications, fellowships, lectures, and symposia on topics of interest to scholars and postdoctoral research fellows. The<a href="http://www.semiticmuseum.fas.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do"> Harvard Semitic Museum</a>, in which NELC is housed, has a superb collection of ancient and medieval artifacts representing many of the cultures of the Middle and Near East. As a university teaching museum, the Semitic Museum is committed to providing access to these materials for study and teaching.</p>

<h2>Fields of Study</h2>

<h3>Ancient Near Eastern Studies</h3>

<p>Ancient Near Eastern studies&rsquo; sub-fields include&nbsp;Akkadian and Sumerian studies, archaeology of the Levant,&nbsp;Hebrew Bible/Old Testament,&nbsp;Iranian studies, and&nbsp;Egyptology.</p>

<h3>Jewish History and Culture</h3>

<p>The program in Jewish History and Culture focuses on the history and literature of the Jewish people from late antiquity to modern times, and is&nbsp;divided chronologically into five periods: the Hebrew Bible in its Jewish interpretive context; ancient Jewish history and culture; medieval Jewish&nbsp;history and culture; modern Jewish&nbsp;history and culture; and modern&nbsp;Jewish literatures.&nbsp;While students generally choose to focus their interests by period, the program itself stresses "vertical" competence: all students are expected to gain some expertise in chronological periods other than their main one.&nbsp;As an alternative to specialization by chronological period, students may choose to focus their studies along thematic lines, for example on the history of Jewish biblical exegesis. Ability to work with classical Hebrew sources in the original is a prerequisite for admission to the program.</p>

<h3>Histories and Cultures of Muslim Societies</h3>

<p>The Histories and Cultures of Muslim Societies&nbsp;program focuses on the histories, literatures, philosophy, religious thought, and legal institutions of Muslim societies. Its primary strength lies in the coverage of a broad range of fields of study in pre-modern and modern periods, particularly with regard to Islamic civilizations in the Near and Middle East. As a result of a growing recognition that the study of Islam and Muslim societies must embrace wider, more inclusive study of the diverse ethnic, racial, and religious groups that have been constituents of Muslim cultures in different parts of the world, the program also provides students the opportunity to engage in the comparative study of Muslim societies, particularly in South Asia and Africa and their complex connections with the Near East.</p>

<p>The program in Histories and Cultures of Muslim Societies currently includes the following subfields:</p>

<ul><li>Arabic Language and Literature (classical and modern)</li>
	<li>Islamic Religion and Culture</li>
	<li>Islamic Intellectual History (especially Philosophy and Theology)</li>
	<li>Islamic Institutional History</li>
	<li>Islamic Law</li>
	<li>Indo-Muslim Culture: The Study of Muslim Societies in South Asia</li>
	<li>Islam in Africa</li>
</ul><h2>Admissions Requirements</h2>

<h3>Writing Sample</h3>

<p>In addition to the application materials requested by GSAS, no application to the Department of Near Eastern Languages and Civilizations will be considered complete unless accompanied by a recent sample of the student's written work (e.g., term paper, senior thesis, master&rsquo;s essay). There is not a specified length for this writing sample. However, one should keep in mind that the admissions committee may not have the time to examine carefully a large writing sample in its entirety. Please upload your writing sample to your online application along with your statement of purpose and unofficial transcript.</p>

<h3>Language Requirements</h3>

<p><strong>For the master of arts (AM) program</strong>: Before seeking admission, applicants will normally have attained a basic knowledge of a Near Eastern language central to their field of concentration. In addition, advanced reading knowledge of either French or German is required before admission; the student will be tested prior to the first week of classes in the first term.</p>

<p><strong>For the doctor of philosophy (PhD) program</strong>: Before seeking admission, applicants will normally have attained an ability to read and comprehend sources in the Near Eastern language central to their field of concentration. In addition, advanced reading knowledge of French or German is required before admission to the doctoral program; the student will be tested prior to the first week of classes in the first term.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.nelc.fas.harvard.edu/">More information</a>&nbsp;is available from the&nbsp;Department of Near Eastern Languages and Civilizations and&nbsp;<em>The GSAS handbook </em>details&nbsp;<a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/near-eastern-languages-and-civilizations">program requirements</a>.</p>
</div><h2><div class="label-above" >Theses &amp; Dissertations</div></h2><a href="https://dash.harvard.edu/handle/1/4927603/browse?value=Near%20Eastern%20Languages%20and%20Civilizations&amp;type=department">Theses &amp; Dissertations for Near Eastern Languages and Civilizations</a></div>

<div id="block-ds-extras-program-faculty" class="block block-ds-extras last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Near Eastern Languages and Civilizations Faculty</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-link"><a href="http://nelc.fas.harvard.edu/people/taxonomy/term/7156">See list of Near Eastern Languages and Civilizations faculty</a></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>

		</div><!-- /#content -->

Among the special strengths of the department are moral and political philosophy, aesthetics, epistemology, philosophy of logic, philosophy of language, the history of analytic philosophy, ancient philosophy, Kant, and Wittgenstein." />

  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <form action="/student-life/new-students/international-student-faq" method="post" id="search-block-form" accept-charset="UTF-8"><div><div class="container-inline form-wrapper" id="edit-inline"><div class="form-item form-type-textfield form-item-solr-keyword">
 <input type="text" id="edit-solr-keyword" name="solr_keyword" value="" size="60" maxlength="128" class="form-text" />
</div>
<div class="form-actions form-wrapper" id="edit-actions"><input type="submit" id="edit-submit" name="" value="Search" class="form-submit" /></div></div><input type="hidden" name="form_build_id" value="form-Bbbf7hAnI3w6I3fQIkEfNCJ4GiliaPncZBYsqO-TMHI" />

  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-program-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="image-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="left banner-image banner-column"><!-- scald=86:medium_banner --><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/thumbnails/image/Jean-Jacques_Rousseau_%28painted_portrait%29.jpg?itok=o_RKdsN2" width="1400" height="500" alt="Jean-Jacques Rousseau" title="Jean-Jacques Rousseau" /><!-- END scald=86 --></div><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>Philosophy</h1></div></div><div class="banner-text-extension banner-column"></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>The<a href="http://philosophy.fas.harvard.edu/graduate-welcome"> graduate program in philosophy</a> at Harvard offers students the opportunity to work and to develop their ideas in a stimulating and supportive community of fellow doctoral students, faculty members, and visiting scholars. Among the special strengths of the department are moral and political philosophy, aesthetics, epistemology, philosophy of logic, philosophy of language, the history of analytic philosophy, ancient philosophy, Kant, and Wittgenstein.</p>

<p>The typical entering class ranges from five to eight students. This small size helps foster a sense of community among doctoral students and ensures that they have substantial access to and interaction with their faculty colleagues.</p>

<p>In addition to the standard PhD in philosophy, the department offers a PhD in classical philosophy in collaboration with the Department of the Classics and a<a href="http://hls.harvard.edu/dept/academics/degree-programs/special-programs/coordinated-jdphd-program/"> coordinated JD/PhD program</a> in conjunction with Harvard Law School.</p>

<p>The department&rsquo;s graduate program is essentially a PhD program. Because the principal employment for men and women with advanced training in philosophy is in college teaching requiring the PhD, the department ordinarily does not admit applicants who wish to study only for the master&rsquo;s (AM) degree. The AM may be taken as a step toward the PhD after a minimum of two terms in residence. A candidate for the AM must satisfy the preliminary, distribution, and logic requirements for the PhD; however, the preliminary requirement is reduced to ten half-courses, and only seven of the eight distribution units are required for the AM. In addition, the second-year paper requirement must be satisfied. There is no language requirement for the AM.</p>

<h2>Admissions Requirements</h2>

<h3>Background in Philosophy</h3>

<p>The department requires that applicants have obtained a solid undergraduate background in philosophy, indicating that they have a good grounding in the history of philosophy, as well as familiarity with contemporary work in ethics, epistemology and metaphysics, and logic.</p>

<h3>Scholarly Potential</h3>

<p>The Admissions Committee looks for evidence of outstanding potential in the field of philosophy as shown in the applicant&rsquo;s academic record, letters of recommendation, and statement of purpose in the application.</p>

<h3>Writing Sample</h3>

<p>A writing sample must be submitted with<strong> </strong>the online application.</p>

<p><strong>Scope:</strong> The sample must address a substantial philosophical problem, whether it is an evaluation or presentation of an argument, or a serious attempt to interpret a difficult text.</p>

<p><strong>Length:</strong> In general, the writing sample should be at least 12 to 15 pages long, but no more than 40 pages; a rough maximum length would be about 25 pages. The admissions committee generally does not have time to read papers longer than this.</p>

<p><strong>Format:</strong> The writing sample should be submitted in electronic format, formatted for 8.5-inch x 11-inch paper, 1-inch margins, with double-spaced text in a common 12 point&nbsp;font, such as Times New Roman.</p>

<p>The Department of Philosophy receives nearly 300 applications each year. We ordinarily expect an entering class of five&nbsp;to eight&nbsp;doctoral students. Although the number of qualified applicants exceeds the number of offers the department can make, we invite all who would like to study philosophy at Harvard to apply.</p>

<p><strong>Note:</strong> Students seeking admission to the <a href="http://hls.harvard.edu/dept/academics/degree-programs/special-programs/coordinated-jdphd-program/">coordinated JD/PhD program</a> must apply to and be separately admitted to Harvard Law School and the Department of Philosophy.</p>

<p><a href="http://philosophy.fas.harvard.edu/graduate-welcome">More information</a> is available from&nbsp;the<a href="http://philosophy.fas.harvard.edu/graduate-welcome"> </a>Department<a href="http://philosophy.fas.harvard.edu/graduate-welcome"> </a>of<a href="http://philosophy.fas.harvard.edu/graduate-welcome"> </a>Philosophy and <a href="/student-life/harvard-resources/student-handbook"><em>The GSAS Student Handbook</em></a>&nbsp;details&nbsp;current<a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/philosophy"> program requirements</a>.</p>
</div><h2><div class="label-above" >Theses &amp; Dissertations</div></h2><a href="https://dash.harvard.edu/handle/1/4927603/browse?value=Philosophy&amp;type=department">Theses &amp; Dissertations for Philosophy</a></div>

<div id="block-ds-extras-program-faculty" class="block block-ds-extras last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Philosophy Faculty</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-link"><a href="http://philosophy.fas.harvard.edu/people/people-terms/department-faculty">See list of Philosophy faculty</a></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>
                            	</div>
		</div><!-- /#content -->

</div>

  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-program-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="image-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="left banner-image banner-column"><!-- scald=90:medium_banner --><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/thumbnails/image/cite-SDE2.G7810_1749_B4%20-%20East%20Asia%20Map_0.jpg?itok=UPye_-OA" width="1400" height="500" alt="East Asia Map" title="East Asia Map" /><!-- END scald=90 --></div><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>Regional Studies–East Asia</h1></div></div><div class="banner-text-extension banner-column"></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p><a href="http://rsea.fas.harvard.edu/home">Regional Studies&ndash;East Asia</a> (RSEA) is a vibrant interdisciplinary area studies program designed to accommodate a wide range of interests and needs for graduate training in the languages, societies, and cultures of East Asia. The program affords students interested in a professional career of engagement with Asia an opportunity to pursue a flexible and varied course of instruction related to their career interests; it also serves the needs of students who wish to enter a PhD program but require further background training in the field of East Asian studies. RSEA prepares students for careers in higher education, politics, the military, journalism, international organizations, and the business and financial sectors.</p>

<p>RSEA dates back to 1946, when renowned China scholar John King Fairbank launched a full-time seminar leading to a master&rsquo;s degree known as Regional Studies&ndash;China; the seminar was later expanded to include Japan, Korea, and Vietnam, and became the AM program known as Regional Studies&ndash;East Asia.</p>

<p>For more than half a century, RSEA transformed the field of East Asian Studies and produced over a thousand alumni in all walks of life. Many of RSEA&rsquo;s alumni have achieved distinction in the academic world or in the world of public service.</p>

<h2>Admissions Requirements</h2>

<p>In evaluating applications, the RSEA admissions committee may consider any and all of the following criteria for admission: proven academic excellence, the extent of appropriate language training and prior experience in East Asia, letters of recommendation, writing ability (as demonstrated by a writing sample no longer than 20 pages), GRE scores and, where applicable, TOFEL scores (a score of at least 100 on the iBT TOEFL&nbsp;is required), together with the student&rsquo;s own statement of purpose and proposed subject of study. In addition, each study plan is evaluated to assess the availability of suitable faculty resources to provide adequate training and supervision to an applicant, if admitted.</p>

<p>Please note that on your application, you are asked to indicate which Harvard faculty member(s) you would like to work with should you be admitted into the program. It is important for you to do so to ensure that faculty members with whom you would like to work are informed when your application becomes available for review. There is no need to contact faculty directly.</p>

<p>Regional Studies&ndash;East Asia provides&nbsp;<a href="http://rsea.fas.harvard.edu/home">more information</a>&nbsp;and an&nbsp;<a href="http://rsea.fas.harvard.edu/admissions/faqs">admission FAQ</a>. The <em>GSAS Student Handbook</em> details&nbsp;<a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/regional-studies-east-asia">program requirements</a>.</p>
</div></div>

<div id="block-ds-extras-program-faculty" class="block block-ds-extras last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Regional Studies–East Asia Faculty</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-link"><a href="https://rsea.fas.harvard.edu/people/faculty">See list of Regional Studies–East Asia faculty</a></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>
                            	</div>

<meta name="description" content="The master’s degree in Regional Studies–Russia, Eastern Europe, and Central Asia (REECA) is a two-year program offering advanced training in the history, politics, culture, society, and languages of this region. The REECA master’s degree offers an excellent foundation for any career that requires broad area expertise, a high level of proficiency in at least one language of the region, and superb research, writing, and communication skills." />

  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <form action="/student-life/new-students/international-student-faq" method="post" id="search-block-form" accept-charset="UTF-8"><div><div class="container-inline form-wrapper" id="edit-inline"><div class="form-item form-type-textfield form-item-solr-keyword">
 <input type="text" id="edit-solr-keyword" name="solr_keyword" value="" size="60" maxlength="128" class="form-text" />
</div>
<div class="form-actions form-wrapper" id="edit-actions"><input type="submit" id="edit-submit" name="" value="Search" class="form-submit" /></div></div><input type="hidden" name="form_build_id" value="form-Bbbf7hAnI3w6I3fQIkEfNCJ4GiliaPncZBYsqO-TMHI" />
