  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-program-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="image-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="left banner-image banner-column"><!-- scald=99:medium_banner --><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/thumbnails/image/East_European_population_and_languages_-_Russian_map_of_1907_0.jpg?itok=MOcpTy9e" width="1400" height="500" alt="1907 Russian Map" title="1907 Russian Map" /><!-- END scald=99 --></div><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>Regional Studies–Russia, Eastern Europe, and Central Asia</h1></div></div><div class="banner-text-extension banner-column"></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>The master&rsquo;s degree in <a href="https://daviscenter.fas.harvard.edu/study/academic-programs/masters-program">Regional Studies&ndash;Russia, Eastern Europe, and Central Asia</a> (REECA) is a two-year program offering advanced training in the history, politics, culture, society, and languages of this region. The REECA master&rsquo;s degree offers an excellent foundation for any career that requires broad area expertise, a high level of proficiency in at least one language of the region, and superb research, writing, and communication skills. REECA alumni pursue careers in a variety of fields, including government service, non-profit management, academia, and the private sector.</p>

<p>The REECA program is based at the <a href="http://daviscenter.fas.harvard.edu/">Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies</a>, which marshals a rich and diverse array of resources to advance the interdisciplinary study of this world region. The Davis Center&rsquo;s 32&nbsp;faculty associates, representing 7&nbsp;disciplines at 4&nbsp;Harvard schools, offer over 160 language and area studies courses each year. Harvard&rsquo;s library and archival resources on the region are unmatched outside of Russia. The Davis Center hosts a full schedule of seminars, conferences, and special events that engage a dynamic and collegial scholarly community. In addition to the academic and extracurricular resources available through the Davis Center, REECA students enjoy access to superior financial aid, including academic year tuition grants and stipends, summer and academic year <a href="https://daviscenter.fas.harvard.edu/study/student-opportunities/east-europe-flas-fellowships">Foreign Language and Area Studies</a> (FLAS) Fellowships, support for research travel and professional development.</p>

<h2>Admissions Requirements</h2>

<p>Admission to the REECA master&rsquo;s program is highly selective and takes place in a single round of competition each year. Applicants are expected to demonstrate the potential for outstanding academic achievement at the graduate level and must present a superior undergraduate record, excellent academic references, high scores on the Graduate Record Examination (GRE) general test, a writing sample, and a compelling statement of purpose that makes clear how the REECA program fits in with their overall academic and/or career goals.</p>

<p>The most competitive applicants have completed substantial prior coursework in language and area studies of the region, especially history and the social sciences. Entering students should have completed the equivalent of at least three years of college-level study of Russian or another regional language. Experience in the region is highly desirable, whether studying abroad, working, or pursuing independent research.</p>

<p>For more information, visit the <a href="http://daviscenter.fas.harvard.edu/study/academic-programs/masters-program">REECA program website</a>. Program requirements are also found in the <a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/regional-studies-russia-eastern-europe-and-central-asia">GSAS Student Handbook</a>.</p>
</div></div>

<div id="block-ds-extras-program-faculty" class="block block-ds-extras last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Regional Studies–Russia, Eastern Europe, and Central Asia Faculty</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-link"><a href="http://daviscenter.fas.harvard.edu/about-us/people">See list of Regional Studies–Russia, Eastern Europe, and Central Asia faculty</a></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>
                            	</div>
		</div><!-- /#content -->

<meta name="description" content="Resources for the study of religion at Harvard are vast. We offer courses in the whole range of religious traditions from the ancient Zoroastrian tradition to modern Christian liberation movements, Islamic and Jewish philosophies, Buddhist social movements, and Hindu arts and culture. Some faculty work primarily as historians, others as scholars of texts, others as anthropologists, although the boundaries of these methodologies are never firm. Some are adherents of a religious tradition; others are not at all religious." />

  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <form action="/student-life/new-students/international-student-faq" method="post" id="search-block-form" accept-charset="UTF-8"><div><div class="container-inline form-wrapper" id="edit-inline"><div class="form-item form-type-textfield form-item-solr-keyword">
 <input type="text" id="edit-solr-keyword" name="solr_keyword" value="" size="60" maxlength="128" class="form-text" />
</div>
<div class="form-actions form-wrapper" id="edit-actions"><input type="submit" id="edit-submit" name="" value="Search" class="form-submit" /></div></div><input type="hidden" name="form_build_id" value="form-Bbbf7hAnI3w6I3fQIkEfNCJ4GiliaPncZBYsqO-TMHI" />
<input type="hidden" name="form_id" value="solr_search_box_form" />

  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-program-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="image-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="left banner-image banner-column"><!-- scald=1359:medium_banner --><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/thumbnails/image/2048px-Palmyra_03.jpg?itok=sQZ9a7Ia" width="1400" height="500" alt="Camels-near-Palmyra" title="Camels-near-Palmyra" /><!-- END scald=1359 --></div><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>Religion</h1></div></div><div class="banner-text-extension banner-column"></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>Resources for the study of religion at Harvard are vast. We offer courses in the whole range of religious traditions from the ancient Zoroastrian tradition to modern Christian liberation movements, Islamic and Jewish philosophies, Buddhist social movements, and Hindu arts and culture. Some faculty work primarily as historians, others as scholars of texts, others as anthropologists, although the boundaries of these methodologies are never firm. Some are adherents of a religious tradition; others are not at all religious. The study of religion is exciting and challenging precisely because of the conversations that take place across the complexities of disciplines, traditions, and intellectual commitments.</p>

<p>The<a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/phd-program"> PhD program in the study of religion</a> dates from 1934, when the Faculty of Arts and Sciences established a degree of PhD in the history and philosophy of religion. Its purpose, as stated by the faculty, was &ldquo;to make possible a course of studies which shall enable the candidate both to lay a broad and sufficient foundation for teaching and study within the field of religion, and to do individual research at some point in that field.&rdquo; In accordance with that expressed intention, the faculty voted in 1963 to name the program the Study of Religion. This program is jointly offered by the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences and the Harvard Divinity School and administered by the Committee on the Study of Religion. Faculty from both schools advise PhD students and offer classes in the program. Students enroll&nbsp;in and receive&nbsp;their PhD from GSAS&nbsp;though they&nbsp;may study primarily with faculty from Harvard Divinity School.</p>

<h2>Admissions Requirements</h2>

<p>Admission to the PhD program in the Study of Religion at Harvard is very competitive: typically only 5&nbsp;to 6 percent&nbsp;of all applicants are admitted. Basic requirements&nbsp;include a bachelor&rsquo;s degree or its equivalent&nbsp;with an undergraduate record of outstanding quality&mdash;a previous master&rsquo;s degree is not required, but it is the rare, exceptional student who is admitted without one. Similarly, while a previous major in the field of religion is not required, the applicant&rsquo;s preparation in this and related subjects is a critical consideration.</p>

<p>Applicants must submit&nbsp;current GRE scores and&nbsp;TOEFL scores if a non-native English speaker, unless the applicant holds a BA degree (or equivalent degree) from an English-speaking university. For&nbsp;the PhD in religion, the minimum iBT TOEFL score&nbsp;is&nbsp;105. In addition, applicants must submit an abstract of courses, three letters of recommendation, and a brief writing sample no more than 10 pages or 2,500 words.&nbsp;A statement of purpose&nbsp;outlining their proposed project is also&nbsp;required.</p>

<p>When applying, prospective students should review the<a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/research"> current fields of research</a>. The Committee on the Study of Religion admits students who have clearly defined intellectual interests evidenced in the statement of purpose and completed application. Applicants may choose only <em>one</em> area of specialization from the list.</p>

<p>In cases where a student&rsquo;s interest span two fields, faculty related to both fields will review the application. Applicants must clearly explain their interdisciplinary interests in their statement of purpose and also state which field would be their primary home. If you find your particular field of interest is not noted<strong>, </strong>please contact us directly.</p>

<h3>Language Requirements</h3>

<p>All doctoral applicants are expected to have foundational language work needed for primary research (textual or ethnographic) in the area of specialization (Greek, Hebrew, Latin, Sanskrit, Arabic, Chinese, etc.) at the time of application. In addition, admitted students must demonstrate reading competence in two modern languages of secondary scholarship relevant to their course of study. These languages are determined in consultation with an advisor after admission to the program,&nbsp;typically German and French.</p>

<p><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/phd-program">More information</a> is available from the&nbsp;Committee on the Study of Religion and the <em>GSAS Student Handbook</em>&nbsp;details&nbsp;<a href="/admissions/apply">program requirements</a>.</p>
</div><h2><div class="label-above" >Theses &amp; Dissertations</div></h2><a href="https://dash.harvard.edu/handle/1/4927603/browse?value=Religion%2C%20Committee%20on%20the%20Study%20of&amp;type=department">Theses &amp; Dissertations for Religion</a></div>

<div id="block-ds-extras-program-faculty" class="block block-ds-extras last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Religion Faculty</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-link"><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/profile-type/faculty">See list of Religion faculty</a></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>
                            	</div>
		</div><!-- /#content -->

            <div class="content">
      <p>African Religions<br>
Buddhist Studies<br>
Comparative Studies<br>
East Asian Religions<br>
Ethics<br>
Greco-Roman Religions<br>
Hebrew Bible<br>
History of Christianity<br>
Islamic Studies<br>
Jewish Studies<br>
New Testament and Early Christianity<br>
Philosophy of Religion<br>
Religion and Society<br>
Religion, Gender, and Culture<br>
Religion in the Americas<br>
Religions of Late Antiquity: Judaism and Christianity<br>
South Asian Religions<br>
Theology</p>

      <ul id="superfish-1" class="menu sf-menu sf-main-menu sf-horizontal sf-style-none sf-total-items-7 sf-parent-items-7 sf-single-items-0 fouc"><li id="menu-1074-1" class="first odd sf-item-1   <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <form action="/student-life/new-students/international-student-faq" method="post" id="search-block-form" accept-charset="UTF-8"><div><div class="container-inline form-wrapper" id="edit-inline"><div class="form-item form-type-textfield form-item-solr-keyword">

</div>
<div class="form-actions form-wrapper" id="edit-actions"><input type="submit" id="edit-submit" name="" value="Search" class="form-submit" /></div></div><input type="hidden" name="form_build_id" value="form-Bbbf7hAnI3w6I3fQIkEfNCJ4GiliaPncZBYsqO-TMHI" />

  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-program-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="gray-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>Romance Languages and Literatures</h1></div></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>Deeply committed to interdisciplinary studies, the <a href="http://rll.fas.harvard.edu/pages/graduate-programs">Department of Romance Languages and Literatures</a> at Harvard encourages graduate students to situate literature in the broad context of cultural productions, ranging from the canonical to alternative modes.</p>

<p>Combining a broad knowledge of each literature through diverse&nbsp;course offerings&nbsp;&nbsp;and specialized research working one-on-one with faculty, our graduate programs nurture students&rsquo; individual interests. A strong sense of community among students and faculty, particularly within specialties, creates a graduate experience as unique as each chosen dissertation topic. Students pursue research topics in the <a href="http://rll.fas.harvard.edu/pages/french-and-francophone">French and Francophone</a>, <a href="http://rll.fas.harvard.edu/pages/italian-0">Italian</a>,<a href="http://rll.fas.harvard.edu/pages/portuguese-and-luso-brazilian"> Portuguese and Luso-Brazilian</a>, or <a href="http://rll.fas.harvard.edu/pages/spanish-and-latin-american">Spanish and Latin American</a> literary traditions, alone or in combination, leading to the PhD.</p>

<p>Our students further enjoy the benefits of interaction with history and literature, studies of women, gender, and sexuality, comparative literature, visual and environmental studies, African American studies, and other programs and departments at Harvard.</p>

<h2>Admissions Requirements</h2>

<p>Admission to the graduate program is based on merit alone. Every offer of admission is accompanied by an offer of full financial aid, consisting of stipend and/or teaching salary, tuition and health fees, and supplemental fellowships available competitively. We also encourage our students to travel and spend time abroad, through our exchange programs with various institutions in France, Italy, Spain, and Latin America, or through other forms of financial and institutional support.</p>

<p>When applying, you must include a writing sample of your best scholarly work in your chosen language of study,&nbsp;not to exceed 15 to 20 double spaced pages, written in the target language..</p>

<p>Prospective applicants in Romance Languages and Literatures often ask about criteria for admissions decisions. The committees assess scholarly promise based on each student's dossier as a whole. We expect high GRE scores of our applicants. We consider test scores to serve as likely indices of academic potential, but also place them in the context of the candidate&rsquo;s overall profile.</p>

<p>To all applicants holding previous master&rsquo;s degrees: At the end of the first year of studies, students may formally request credit for up to four semester-long courses taken elsewhere.</p>

<p>Visit<a href="http://rll.fas.harvard.edu/pages/graduate-programs"> Department of Romance Languages and Literatures</a> for more information and the <em>GSAS Student Handbook</em> for<a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/romance-languages-and-literatures"> program requirements</a>.</p>
</div><h2><div class="label-above" >Theses &amp; Dissertations</div></h2><a href="https://dash.harvard.edu/handle/1/4927603/browse?value=Romance%20Languages%20and%20Literatures&amp;type=department">Theses &amp; Dissertations for Romance Languages and Literatures</a></div>

<div id="block-ds-extras-program-faculty" class="block block-ds-extras last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Romance Languages and Literatures Faculty</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-link"><a href="http://rll.fas.harvard.edu/people/faculty">See list of Romance Languages and Literatures faculty</a></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>
                            	</div>
		</div><!-- /#content -->

<meta name="description" content="The Department of Slavic Languages and Literatures offers graduate students the opportunity to study the literatures, cultures, and languages of the Slavic world, including especially Russia, Ukraine, Poland, the Czech Republic, Bosnia, Croatia, and Serbia. The department offers interdisciplinary and comparative courses across the cultures of the Slavic world, encouraging a wide variety of specializations from literature to film, art, and visual culture." />

  <title>Slavic Languages and Literatures | Harvard University - The Graduate School of Arts and Sciences</title>

<div id="block-solr-search-block-solr-search-block" class="block block-solr-search-block last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <form action="/student-life/new-students/international-student-faq" method="post" id="search-block-form" accept-charset="UTF-8"><div><div class="container-inline form-wrapper" id="edit-inline"><div class="form-item form-type-textfield form-item-solr-keyword">
 <input type="text" id="edit-solr-keyword" name="solr_keyword" value="" size="60" maxlength="128" class="form-text" />
</div>
<div class="form-actions form-wrapper" id="edit-actions"><input type="submit" id="edit-submit" name="" value="Search" class="form-submit" /></div></div><input type="hidden" name="form_build_id" value="form-Bbbf7hAnI3w6I3fQIkEfNCJ4GiliaPncZBYsqO-TMHI" />
<input type="hidden" name="form_id" value="solr_search_box_form" />
</div></form>    </div>

  </div><!-- /#navigation -->
  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-program-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="image-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="left banner-image banner-column"><!-- scald=101:medium_banner --><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/thumbnails/image/Moscow_State_Historical_Museum_Red_Square.jpg?itok=s581BRaH" width="1400" height="500" alt="Moscow Historical Museum" title="Moscow Historical Museum" /><!-- END scald=101 --></div><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>Slavic Languages and Literatures</h1></div></div><div class="banner-text-extension banner-column"></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>The<a href="http://slavic.fas.harvard.edu/pages/graduate">&nbsp;<strong>Department of Slavic Languages and Literatures</strong></a>&nbsp;offers graduate students the opportunity to study the literatures, cultures, and languages of the Slavic world, including especially Russia, Ukraine, Poland, the Czech Republic, Bosnia,&nbsp;Croatia, and Serbia. The department offers interdisciplinary and comparative courses across the cultures of the Slavic world, encouraging a wide variety of specializations from literature to film, art, and visual culture.</p>

<p>Most of our doctoral candidates specialize in literature, working closely with faculty in their major fields to create a program oriented around their particular interests; coursework is possible in allied fields (such as History, Anthropology, Government, Film, and Music) as well. Many of our students also do work in linguistics; aAll students study Old Church Slavonic and take a practical linguistics course as part of their preparation for teaching language courses.</p>

<p>Faculty in the department teach a wide range of courses, from medieval to contemporary culture. These courses take many different approaches, drawing on &nbsp;cultural studies, formalism, gender studies, linguistics, philology, political theory, post-structuralism, psychoanalysis, semiotics, structuralism, and visual studies, among others. The program aims to provide students with a broad knowledge of the field as well as a sense of historical depth. We emphasize the ability to write well, to do innovative scholarly and critical work, and to make effective presentations at conferences and symposia. Teaching effectively is a skill we seek to cultivate in all our students, preparing them for both literature and language courses. The program takes from five to eight years to complete, with most students completing the PhD degree in six or seven years, often including dissertation research abroad.</p>

<p>The department maintains close working ties with other departments and centers studying the Slavic world at Harvard, including the&nbsp;<a href="http://daviscenter.fas.harvard.edu/"><strong>Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies</strong></a> (which sponsors its own <a href="/programs-of-study/all/regional-studies-russia-eastern-europe-and-central-asia"><strong>Master&rsquo;s Degree program</strong></a> in Russia, Eastern Europe, and Central Asia) and the<a href="http://www.huri.harvard.edu/"><strong>&nbsp;Harvard Ukrainian Research Institute</strong></a>. The Harvard Film Archive houses an extensive and unique collection devoted to Russian and Soviet cinema, which includes 35- and 16-millimeter films.</p>

<p>The department requires that doctoral candidates work as teaching fellows in its language and literature courses, regarding such experience as an integral part of doctoral training. Students normally teach in the third and fourth years of study, and often beyond.</p>

<p>If you are interested in a terminal master&rsquo;s degree, please review information on the&nbsp;<a href="http://daviscenter.fas.harvard.edu/study/academic-programs/masters-program"><strong>master&rsquo;s degree in Regional Studies: Russia, Eastern Europe, and Central Asia (REECA)</strong></a>&nbsp;offered by the&nbsp;<a href="http://daviscenter.fas.harvard.edu/"><strong>Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies</strong></a>.</p>

<h2>Admissions Requirements</h2>

<p>We welcome applicants with traditional and non-traditional preparation in the field, as long as their foreign-language, linguistic, and literary-studies skills are strong. Applicants should show knowledge of Russian (or the language of the student's major field) equivalent to the Harvard class &ldquo;Advanced Russian II: Reading, Composition, and Conversation.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Formal training in literature or linguistics is highly desirable for admission. In order to anticipate the language requirement, it helps for a candidate to have a reading knowledge of French or German, although this is not a prerequisite.</p>

<p>No application for admission will be considered complete unless accompanied by a recent and extensive sample (usually 20-25 pages) of the student&rsquo;s written work in English.</p>

<p>The department ordinarily interviews finalists for admission by Skype in late January and early February. Admitted students are encouraged to come to campus whenever they are able for a one-day visit, usually in February or March, to meet with the faculty and graduate students and to find out more about our programs of study.</p>

<p>We also welcome potential candidates who wish to come to Cambridge for informational interviews during the spring or fall before submitting an application. Contact the<a href="http://slavic.fas.harvard.edu/pages/contact"><strong>&nbsp;department administrator</strong></a>&nbsp;to arrange meetings with individual faculty members. In such cases, candidates should also arrange to meet with the current director of graduate studies for Slavic and possibly the department chair.</p>

<p><a href="http://slavic.fas.harvard.edu/pages/graduate"><strong>More information</strong></a>&nbsp;is available from the&nbsp;Department of Slavic Languages and Literatures&nbsp;and the&nbsp;<em>GSAS Student Handbook</em>&nbsp;for&nbsp;<a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/slavic-languages-and-literatures"><strong>program requirements</strong></a>.</p>
</div><h2><div class="label-above" >Theses &amp; Dissertations</div></h2><a href="https://dash.harvard.edu/handle/1/4927603/browse?value=Slavic%20Languages%20and%20Literatures&amp;type=department">Theses &amp; Dissertations for Slavic Languages and Literatures</a></div>

<div id="block-ds-extras-program-faculty" class="block block-ds-extras last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Slavic Languages and Literatures Faculty</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-link"><a href="http://slavic.fas.harvard.edu/people-taxonomy/faculty">See list of Slavic Languages and Literatures faculty</a></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>
                            	</div>
		</div><!-- /#content -->

<meta name="description" content="The Department of South Asian Studies offers programs of study leading to the doctor of philosophy (PhD) and, in exceptional cases, the master of arts (AM) degrees. While graduate work is tailored to individual intellectual interests, all doctoral students are expected to ground their work in primary language materials and participate in broadly interdisciplinary studies of South Asian languages, histories, and cultures." />
<meta name="generator" content="Drupal 7 (http://drupal.org)" />

<div id="block-superfish-1" class="block block-superfish plain even">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <ul id="superfish-1" class="menu sf-menu sf-main-menu sf-horizontal sf-style-none sf-total-items-7 sf-parent-items-7 sf-single-items-0 fouc"><li id="menu-1074-1" class="first odd sf-item-1   <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <form action="/student-life/new-students/international-student-faq" method="post" id="search-block-form" accept-charset="UTF-8"><div><div class="container-inline form-wrapper" id="edit-inline"><div class="form-item form-type-textfield form-item-solr-keyword">
 <input type="text" id="edit-solr-keyword" name="solr_keyword" value="" size="60" maxlength="128" class="form-text" />
</div>
<div class="form-actions form-wrapper" id="edit-actions"><input type="submit" id="edit-submit" name="" value="Search" class="form-submit" /></div></div><input type="hidden" name="form_build_id" value="form-Bbbf7hAnI3w6I3fQIkEfNCJ4GiliaPncZBYsqO-TMHI" />

  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-program-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="image-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="left banner-image banner-column"><!-- scald=94:medium_banner --><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/thumbnails/image/MapofEelamTamilcountryengraving1692.jpg?itok=_PX7YdBr" width="1400" height="500" alt="Sri Lanka 1681 map" title="Sri Lanka 1681 map" /><!-- END scald=94 --></div><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>South Asian Studies</h1></div></div><div class="banner-text-extension banner-column"></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-program view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>The<a href="http://sas.fas.harvard.edu/graduate"> Department of South Asian Studies</a> offers programs of study leading to the doctor of philosophy (PhD) and, in exceptional cases, the master of arts (AM) degrees. While graduate work is tailored to individual intellectual interests, all doctoral students are expected to ground their work in primary language materials and participate in broadly interdisciplinary studies of South Asian languages, histories, and cultures.</p>

<p>The department has historic and well-defined courses of graduate study in Sanskrit and Indian studies and Tibetan and Himalayan studies. It is our expectation that candidates for doctoral study will propose other programs in South Asian studies. Such programs may have a regional emphasis, a disciplinary or multi-disciplinary emphasis, or an emphasis on a particular era of South Asian history, including modern South Asia. Some of the most exciting multi-disciplinary work in the global academy today has been pioneered by scholars of South Asian Studies, and this program intends to provide a platform for such study here at Harvard.</p>

<p>All of the department&rsquo;s PhD programs emphasize the study of South Asian languages as foundational for scholarly work. Currently, members of the department focus in their own work on Hindi-Urdu (including Avadhi, Braj, and modern dialects), Middle Indic (Pali, Prakrit), Nepali, Sanskrit (Vedic, Classical), Tamil (Classical, Modern), and Tibetan (Classical, Modern). The department also supports instruction in Bahasa Indonesia, Bengali, Burmese, Gujarati, Sindhi, and Thai. Persian is regularly offered through the Department of Near Eastern Languages and Civilizations.</p>

<p>We emphasize a rigorous approach to South Asian texts and traditions, the cultural, intellectual, and social practices that they inform, and the diverse disciplinary perspectives that are needed to study and write about them. Students are encouraged to view their chosen topics in their historical contexts while also exploring their significance to ongoing South Asian traditions and/or to contemporary issues in the humanities and social sciences.</p>

<p>In exceptional cases, the department will admit&nbsp;to a one year AM program&nbsp;particularly promising students who would like to strengthen their background in South Asian studies but who may not have all of the qualifications for doctoral study. Applicants should be aware that there is no funding available for AM candidates.</p>

<h2>Admission Requirements</h2>

<p>Admission to the PhD program is offered on the basis of an outstanding academic record, letters of recommendation, a writing sample, and, ordinarily, GRE scores. A strong background in one or more areas of South Asian studies is required. For admission to the Sanskrit and Indian studies program, prerequisites include two years of Sanskrit, and for the Tibetan and Himalayan studies program, two years of classical Tibetan. These language requirements correspond to the first and second years of Sanskrit or Tibetan taught at Harvard. For the South Asian studies program, candidates should have at least two years of study in a South Asian language. The student&rsquo;s command of the relevant languages will be evaluated during the first term.</p>

<p>Applicants with the requisite background should <a href="mailto:southasianstudies@fas.harvard.edu">e-mail the department</a> well before the admissions deadline. Please describe your previous academic work in South Asian studies and your specific research interests. Include the names of faculty members with whom you might wish to work.</p>

<p>Visit the Department of South Asian Studies for<a href="http://sas.fas.harvard.edu/graduate"> more information</a> and the <em>GSAS Student Handbook</em> for<a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/south-asian-studies"> program requirements</a>.</p>
</div><h2><div class="label-above" >Theses &amp; Dissertations</div></h2><a href="https://dash.harvard.edu/handle/1/4927603/browse?value=South%20Asian%20Studies&amp;type=department">Theses &amp; Dissertations for South Asian Studies</a></div>

<div id="block-ds-extras-program-faculty" class="block block-ds-extras last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">South Asian Studies Faculty</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-field-link"><a href="http://sas.fas.harvard.edu/people/taxonomy/term/18441">See list of South Asian Studies faculty</a></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>
                            	</div>
		</div><!-- /#content -->

  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-page-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="image-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="left banner-image banner-column"><!-- scald=1270:medium_banner --><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/thumbnails/image/Whitney-Silkworth_06_edited.jpg?itok=akukaXDT" width="1400" height="500" alt="Whitney Silkworth" title="Whitney Silkworth" /><!-- END scald=1270 --></div><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><h1>Programs of Study</h1><div class="field field-name-field-banner-teaser"><p>GSAS awards the PhD and&nbsp;select terminal master&rsquo;s degrees in 56 programs across all disciplines.</p>
</div></div></div><div class="banner-text-extension banner-column"></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-page view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>We offer&nbsp;a broad array of PhD programs and a select number of master's programs in the arts and sciences. Our partnerships with the other schools at Harvard University enable us to offer flexible programs of study and combined degrees.</p>
</div></div>

<div id="block-gsas-menu-block-main-menu" class="block block-gsas-menu-block plain last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div  class="ds-1col node node-page node-teaser view-mode-teaser clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-title"><h2><a href="/programs-study/degree-programs">Degree Programs</a></h2></div><div class="field field-name-body">The Graduate School of Arts and Sciences offers the master of arts (AM), master of science (SM), master of engineering (ME), and the doctor of philosophy (PhD) in 56 divisions, departments, and committees, including 17 interfaculty programs.<a href="/programs-study/degree-programs" class="more-link">Read more</a></div></div>

<div  class="ds-1col node node-page node-teaser view-mode-teaser clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-title"><h2><a href="/programs-study/non-degree-programs">Non-Degree Programs</a></h2></div><div class="field field-name-body">https://www.extension.harvard.edu/sites/extension.harvard.edu/files/atoms/files/ext_special_student_petition.pdf Each year, we welcome to our diverse academic community a select group of non-degree scholars from around the globe as special students and visiting fellows.<a href="/programs-study/non-degree-programs" class="more-link">Read more</a></div></div>

<div  class="ds-1col node node-page node-teaser view-mode-teaser clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-title"><h2><a href="/programs-study/secondary-fields">Secondary Fields</a></h2></div><div class="field field-name-body">PhD students interested in pursuing a secondary field take four or five graduate courses in a discipline, interdisciplinary area, or intellectually coherent subfield. The program offering the secondary field provides an intellectual rationale and outlines the package of courses required. See the...<a href="/programs-study/secondary-fields" class="more-link">Read more</a></div></div>

<div  class="ds-1col node node-page node-teaser view-mode-teaser clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-title"><h2><a href="/joint-degrees">Combined Degrees</a></h2></div><div class="field field-name-body">GSAS enables PhD students to coordinate their studies for an additional advanced degree.<a href="/joint-degrees" class="more-link">Read more</a></div></div>

    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>
                            	</div>
		</div><!-- /#content -->
                                
              </div><!-- /#main-content -->

          <span class="views-field-division-abbreviation"><a href="https://gsas.harvard.edu/programs-of-study/divisions/division-medical-sciences"><span class="tooltip" data-term="Division of Medical Sciences" data-link="MORE" data-url="/programs-of-study/divisions/division-medical-sciences" title="This program is offered through the Division of Medical Sciences.">DMS</span></a></span>        
          <span class="views-field-division-abbreviation"><a href="https://gsas.harvard.edu/programs-of-study/divisions/harvard-integrated-life-sciences"><span class="tooltip" data-term="Harvard Integrated Life Sciences" data-link="MORE" data-url="/programs-of-study/divisions/harvard-integrated-life-sciences" title="Harvard's cross-disciplinary life sciences graduate program.">HILS</span></a></span>            </td>
                  <td class="views-field views-field-field-application-deadline">
            <span class="date-display-single">Dec 1, 2017</span>          </td>
                  <td class="views-field views-field-field-degrees-offered">
            Doctor of Philosophy (PhD)          </td>
              </tr></tbody></table></div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div>
    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </section>

                <div class="content">
      <form action="/student-life/new-students/international-student-faq" method="post" id="search-block-form" accept-charset="UTF-8"><div><div class="container-inline form-wrapper" id="edit-inline"><div class="form-item form-type-textfield form-item-solr-keyword">

  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-page-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="gray-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="banner-image banner-column"><div class="banner-image-bg" style="background-image: url(https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/profile_footer/public/thumbnails/image/AnthonyCovarrubis_13_edited.jpg?itok=6UdPhSVM);"><!-- scald=1306:profile_footer --><img src="https://gsas.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/styles/profile_footer/public/thumbnails/image/AnthonyCovarrubis_13_edited.jpg?itok=6UdPhSVM" width="850" height="510" alt="Anthony Covarrubis" title="Anthony Covarrubis" /><!-- END scald=1306 --></div></div><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><nav class="breadcrumb" role="navigation"><h2 class="element-invisible">You are here</h2><ol><li><a href="/programs-study">Programs of Study</a></li></ol></nav><h1>Non-Degree Programs</h1><div class="field field-name-field-banner-teaser"><p>Each year, we welcome to our diverse academic community a select group of non-degree scholars from around the globe as special students and visiting fellows.</p>
</div></div></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>
</div><!-- /.block -->
  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-page view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><h2>Special Students</h2>

<p>Individuals with academic or professional reasons for pursuing graduate-level study without entering a degree program&nbsp;may register as special students and engage in coursework or a combination of coursework and research for academic credit, for one term or one year only. While they are not candidates for any degree, special students are much like first-year graduate students; they participate in coursework and may request an official Harvard transcript of courses and grades received.</p>

<p>As a special student, you are admitted to GSAS and have access to most student privileges. You are eligible to enroll in graduate or undergraduate courses, depending on your academic record. You must hold a bachelor&rsquo;s degree or its equivalent and must present evidence of fitness for admission at the graduate level. <a href="/admissions/tuition-fees">Full tuition</a>&nbsp;is charged and you are not eligible for institutional financial aid. Tuition cannot be waived or reduced.</p>

<h4>Harvard Extension School ALB and ALM Candidates</h4>

<p>Harvard Extension School students working toward an ALB or ALM degree who wish to take courses not offered at Harvard Extension School or Harvard Summer School may enroll as a GSAS special student, taking two courses per term for one academic year.</p>

<p>To qualify, candidates must earn a minimum number of Harvard Extension School credits with a specific GPA and obtain recommendations from their program director and two Harvard Extension School instructors. For more information, ALM candidates should review the<a href="http://www.extension.harvard.edu/sites/extension.harvard.edu/files/atoms/files/ext_psss_0.pdf"> Special Student Information Sheet</a>&nbsp;[PDF] and ALB candidates should review<a href="https://www.extension.harvard.edu/sites/extension.harvard.edu/files/atoms/files/ext_stp.pdf"> </a><a href="https://www.extension.harvard.edu/sites/extension.harvard.edu/files/atoms/files/ext_special_student_petition.pdf">Special Student Procedures</a>.</p>

<h2>Visiting Fellows</h2>

<p>Scholars intending to conduct independent research who hold a doctorate, have equivalent professional experience, or are advanced doctoral candidates who have completed all required coursework, may register at GSAS as a visiting fellow. Visiting fellows are considered full-time research students, with access to Harvard University&rsquo;s libraries and facilities, and may apply for membership in the Harvard Faculty Club. While visiting fellows do not take courses for academic credit, they may audit courses with the approval of the instructor and seek faculty guidance as they conduct independent research. Please note that visiting fellows are normally not permitted to audit basic skills courses such as beginning languages or computer science.</p>

<p>In order to be considered for visiting fellow status, a scholar should note in their application the name of any faculty members with whom they intend to work&nbsp;and reference&nbsp;any communication with&nbsp;faculty members or academic departments. While visiting fellows are occasionally invited by departments or research centers to participate in seminars or other organized activities, they are expected to conduct their research independently.</p>

<p>Visiting fellows are charged <a href="/admissions/tuition-fees">Reduced Tuition</a>, which may not be waived, and they are not eligible for institutional financial aid. Please note that visiting fellow status is full&nbsp;time.</p>

<h2 class="xpandable">Programs of Study and Course Selection</h2>

<p>Before applying for special student or visiting fellow status, scholars should select one department to affiliate with based on their academic interests. While applicants seeking more interdisciplinary opportunities may choose the General Studies Program, GSAS reserves the right to send an application to a specific admissions committee if a candidate&rsquo;s experience and interests are more suited to a particular department.</p>

<ul><li><a href="http://aaas.fas.harvard.edu/"><strong>African and African American Studies</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://americanstudies.fas.harvard.edu/"><strong>American Studies</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~anthro/"><strong>Anthropology</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="https://www.cfa.harvard.edu/"><strong>Astronomy</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/academics/biological-sciences/"><strong>Biological Sciences in Public Health</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://arep.med.harvard.edu/biophysics/"><strong>Biophysics</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.biostat.harvard.edu/"><strong>Biostatistics</strong></a></li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.hbs.edu/doctoral/programs/busec/">Business Economics</a>*&dagger;</strong></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~celtic/"><strong>Celtic Languages and Literatures</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://chemistry.harvard.edu/"><strong>Chemistry and Chemical Biology</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~classics/"><strong>The Classics</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~complit/"><strong>Comparative Literature</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="/programs-of-study/divisions/division-medical-sciences"><strong>Division of Medical Sciences</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.deas.harvard.edu/"><strong>School of Engineering and Applied Sciences</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.eps.harvard.edu/"><strong>Earth and Planetary Sciences</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://ealc.fas.harvard.edu/"><strong>East Asian Languages and Civilizations</strong></a></li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.economics.harvard.edu/">Economics</a>*</strong></li>
	<li><a href="http://english.fas.harvard.edu"><strong>English</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="https://ves.fas.harvard.edu"><strong>Film and </strong></a><a href="https://ves.fas.harvard.edu"><strong>Visual</strong></a><a href="https://ves.fas.harvard.edu"><strong> Studies</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~german/"><strong>Germanic Languages and Literatures</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.gov.harvard.edu/"><strong>Government</strong></a>&Dagger;</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~healthpl/">Health Policy</a>&dagger;</strong></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~history/"><strong>History</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~hoart/"><strong>History of Art and Architecture</strong></a></li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~hsdept/">History of Science</a>*</strong>&sect;</li>
	<li><a href="http://www.heb.fas.harvard.edu/"><strong>Human Evolutionary Biology</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~lingdept/"><strong>Linguistics</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.math.harvard.edu/"><strong>Mathematics</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="https://cmes.fas.harvard.edu"><strong>Middle Eastern Studies</strong></a>&sect;</li>
	<li><a href="/programs-of-study/all/molecular-and-cellular-biology">Molecular and Cellular Biology</a><strong>*</strong></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~musicdpt/"><strong>Music</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://nelc.fas.harvard.edu/"><strong>Near Eastern Languages and Civilizations</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="/programs-of-study/all/organismic-and-evolutionary-biology"><strong>Organismic and Evolutionary Biology</strong></a></li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.hbs.edu/doctoral/programs/ob/">Organizational Behavior</a></strong>*&dagger;</li>
	<li><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~phildept/"><strong>Philosophy</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.physics.harvard.edu/"><strong>Physics</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="https://www.hks.harvard.edu/education/doctoral-programs/phd-political-economy-government"><strong>Political Economy and Government</strong></a>*&dagger;&Dagger;</li>
	<li><a href="http://www.wjh.harvard.edu/psych/"><strong>Psychology</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="https://www.hks.harvard.edu/education/doctoral-programs/phd-public-policy"><strong>Public Policy</strong></a>*&dagger;&Dagger;</li>
	<li><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~csrel/"><strong>Religion</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://rll.fas.harvard.edu/"><strong>Romance Languages and Literatures</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://daviscenter.fas.harvard.edu/about-us"><strong>Regional Studies&mdash;Russia, Eastern Europe, and Central Asia</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~slavic/"><strong>Slavic Languages and Literatures</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.ksg.harvard.edu/socialpol/"><strong>Social Policy</strong></a></li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://sociology.fas.harvard.edu/">Sociology</a>*</strong></li>
	<li><a href="http://sas.fas.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do"><strong>South Asian Studies</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~stats/"><strong>Statistics</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://sysbiophd.harvard.edu/"><strong>Systems Biology</strong></a></li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://wgs.fas.harvard.edu/">Women, Gender, and Sexuality</a>&dagger;</strong></li>
</ul><p><em>* Applicants must have the confirmed support of at least one faculty member to be considered.<br>
&dagger; Accepts applications for visiting fellow status only.</em><br>
&Dagger;<em>The Department of Government and the committees on Public Policy and on Political Economy and Government do not permit affiliation as a special student if you plan to apply for PhD study within 18 months.</em><br>
&sect;&nbsp;<em>Only special student applications are considered; research students should inquire directly with the department.</em></p>

<h3>Course Selection</h3>

<p>To review the courses offered during a particular term, access the <a href="https://courses.harvard.edu/index.html">Public Course Catalog</a>.&nbsp;Courses marked with an asterisk require instructor approval before you can register and those in brackets are not offered during the current term, but may be offered in the future. Special students are restricted from participating in a <a href="/restricted-courses">select group of departmental offerings</a>.</p>

<p>Special students may audit coursework upon securing approval of the course instructor, who determines the level of participation. A grade is not received for the course, but the student&rsquo;s transcript will reference &ldquo;TIME-A.&rdquo; Full tuition is charged for an officially audited course.</p>

<p>Special students may also participate in a supervised independent research project in lieu of a half-course, after securing approval from a faculty member. While a grade is not received for the course, the student&rsquo;s transcript will reference &ldquo;TIME-C.&rdquo; Full tuition is charged.</p>

<h4>Cross Registration</h4>

<p>Special students may enroll in a limited number of courses (not more than half of one&rsquo;s total program per term) in other Harvard faculties or cooperating schools. Learn more by reviewing Harvard&rsquo;s<a href="http://coursecatalog.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do?keyword=CourseCatalog&amp;tabgroupid=icb.tabgroup104752"> cross-registration procedures</a>. Enrollment cannot be guaranteed in advance of registration.</p>
</div></div>

<div id="block-gsas-menu-block-main-menu" class="block block-gsas-menu-block plain last even">

	<div class="region-wrapper">
    <div id="block-block-27" class="block block-block fog-block first odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Application Deadlines</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <p>There are two application cycles each year:</p>

<p><strong>March 1&nbsp;</strong>for full academic year (September to May) or fall term only (September to December)&nbsp;<em>Admitted students are notified by June 1</em><br><strong>October 1</strong>&nbsp;for spring term only (January to May)&nbsp;<em>Admitted students are notified by December 1</em></p>

<p><a class="button-large" href="/apply-non-degree-programs">How to apply</a></p>

<p><a class="button-large" href="https://app.applyyourself.com/AYApplicantLogin/fl_ApplicantConnectLogin.asp?id=hgsas-ssvf">Submit Online&nbsp;Application</a></p>
    </div>
  </div>

  <div class="field field-name-field-contact-info"><p>Special Students and Visiting Fellows Office<br>
Phone: 617-495-5315<br>
E-mail:&nbsp;<a href="mailto:special@fas.harvard.edu">special@fas.harvard.edu</a></p>

<div id="block-block-4" class="block block-block plain last even">
  <div class="block-inner">
              <h2 class="block__title block-title">Contact Us</h2>
            <div class="content">
      <h4>Harvard&nbsp;University</h4>

<h3>Graduate School of Arts &amp; Sciences</h3>

<p>Richard A. and Susan F. Smith Campus Center<br>
1350 Massachusetts Avenue, Suite 350<br>
Cambridge, MA 02138-3654</p>

<p><a class="gmap-icon" href="https://www.google.com/maps/place/1350+Massachusetts+Ave,+Cambridge,+MA+02138/@42.3727139,-71.1210444,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m2!3m1!1s0x89e37742dc1c29a7:0xc3dbda7a42311d03" title="Harvard University - The Graduate School of Arts &amp; Sciences on Google Map">MAP IT</a></p>

<p><span class="uppercase-label">TEL</span>617-495-5315<br><span class="uppercase-label">FAX</span>617-495-2928<br><span class="uppercase-label">EMAIL</span><a href="mailto:gsas@fas.harvard.edu">gsas@fas.harvard.edu</a></p>
    </div>
  </div>

  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">

  <div id="main">
    <div class="wrapper">
      <div id="banner">
          <div class="region region-highlighted">
    <div id="block-ds-extras-page-banner" class="block block-ds-extras plain first last odd">
  <div class="block-inner">
                <div class="content">
      <div class="field field-name-banner"><div class="gray-banner"><div class="position-wrapper"><div class="gutter-wrapper"><div class="banner-text banner-column"><div class="wrapper"><nav class="breadcrumb" role="navigation"><h2 class="element-invisible">You are here</h2><ol><li><a href="/programs-study">Programs of Study</a></li><li><a href="/programs-study/non-degree-programs">Non-Degree Programs</a></li></ol></nav><h1>Special Students & Visiting Fellows FAQ</h1></div></div></div></div></div></div>    </div>
  </div>

  </div>
      </div>
      <div id="main-content">
        <div id="content" class="column" role="main">
			<div class="wrapper">
          <div class="utilities">
      	          	              </div>
          <a id="main-content"></a>
                                <section class="region region-content">
      

<div  class="ds-1col node node-page view-mode-full clearfix">

  
  <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden" ><p>We've collected a list of&nbsp;frequently asked questions to help you with your transition to GSAS.</p>

<h2 class="xpandable">Special Students&nbsp;</h2>

<p><strong>Can I affiliate with more than one department or program?</strong><br>
Special student applicants must choose one department or program with which to affiliate based on their proposed plan of study. If you demonstrate that your academic interests are truly interdisciplinary, you may choose general studies, however, very few students will be admitted from this category.</p>

<p><strong>If I was denied admission to a GSAS degree program, can I apply for special student status?</strong><br>
Individuals denied admission to a degree program at GSAS cannot apply as a special student for the same academic year.</p>

<p><strong>Can special students transfer into a degree-seeking program?</strong><br>
While special students participate in coursework or a combination of coursework and research, they may not transfer to a degree-seeking program. They may, however, apply to GSAS at a later date.</p>

<p><strong>If I am admitted to GSAS after I study as a special student, will my credits count toward my program?</strong><br>
Special students who later apply and are admitted to a GSAS degree program <a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/credit-graduate-work-done-elsewhere">may petition to apply </a>their academic and financial credit toward their degree requirements.</p>

<p><strong>As a special student, can I register in limited-enrollment courses?</strong><br>
Priority is reserved for degree-seeking students. Official enrollment into any course is always subject to the approval of the instructor.</p>

<p><strong>Can I focus only on an independent research project?</strong><br>
An independent research project must count for no more than half of the courses you are enrolled in.</p>

<p><strong>Can I conduct premedical coursework and receive advising as a special student?</strong><br>
The GSAS Special Students and Visiting Fellows Office does not offer a premedical advising program. Premedical students must access the career counseling and placement services offered at their undergraduate institutions.</p>

<p><strong>Can special students take courses during the summer?</strong><br>
GSAS does not offer coursework during the summer. Those interested in taking summer courses may register through<a href="http://www.summer.harvard.edu/"> Harvard Summer School</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Can special students enroll in courses at another Harvard school?</strong><br>
Yes. Special students may, with instructor consent,&nbsp;enroll in courses at other Harvard schools via the <a href="https://courses.harvard.edu/crossregistration.html">cross-registration process</a>. However, students may not take more than 50 percent of their classes outside of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences.</p>

<p><strong>I&rsquo;m an undergraduate at another institution. Can I take Harvard classes?</strong><br>
Students currently enrolled in undergraduate programs elsewhere who wish to take undergraduate courses at Harvard should contact the<a href="https://college.harvard.edu/admissions/application-process/visiting-undergraduate-student-program"> Visiting Undergraduate Student Program</a>.</p>

<h2 class="xpandable">Visiting Fellows&nbsp;</h2>

<p><strong>Can I affiliate with more than one department or program?</strong><br>
Visiting fellows should choose one department or program to affiliate with based on their academic interests.</p>

<p><strong>Can I take a course for credit as a visiting fellow?</strong><br>
Visiting fellows may audit courses with the permission of the instructor. Those interested in taking courses for credit may apply for Special Student status.</p>

<p><strong>If I was denied admission to a GSAS degree program, can I apply for visiting fellow status?</strong><br>
Individuals denied admission to a degree program at GSAS cannot apply as a visiting fellow for the same academic year.</p>

<p><strong>Can I audit a class at another Harvard School or local university?</strong><br>
Visiting fellows may audit courses at Harvard Business School, Harvard Divinity School, and Harvard Law School (Harvard Business School charges auditors a cross-registration materials fee) with instructor permission. They may also audit courses at MIT and the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University with permission from the course&rsquo;s instructor.</p>

<p><strong>As a visiting fellow, can I apply to a degree-seeking program?</strong><br>
While visiting fellows maintain an affiliation with a department and seek advice from faculty, they conduct their research independently and may not apply to a degree-seeking program.</p>

<p><strong>I&rsquo;m a faculty member at another university. Can I register as a visiting fellow?</strong><br>
Faculty members from other universities whose scholarship distinguishes them in their field may be eligible for an academic appointment as visiting scholar. Contact your academic department of interest to inquire about their policy.</p>

<p><strong>I want to be a visiting fellow at another Harvard School. Can I apply through GSAS?</strong><br>
Harvard University offers many opportunities to engage in research. Scholars wishing to concentrate their research at a Harvard graduate school other than GSAS should contact the School&rsquo;s admissions office directly to determine their policy.</p>

<h2 class="xpandable">International Students and Fellows</h2>

<p><strong>How many courses are international special students required to take each term?</strong><br>
Visa requirements specify that international special students must be enrolled full time while registered at GSAS, which equates to 16 credits, or four&nbsp;semester-long courses.</p>

<p><strong>Do audited courses or independent research study count toward my visa requirements?</strong><br>
Officially audited classes are counted toward the four-courses required for international students; you may audit no more than half of the courses you are enrolled in.</p>

<p><strong>Will Harvard sponsor my visa?</strong><br>
Yes! Individuals who are not US citizens ordinarily conduct their studies on a Harvard-sponsored student (F-1) visa. A Harvard-sponsored Exchange Scholar (J-1) visa will be issued upon request based on formal exchange agreement requirements. Visa arrangements cannot be made until the applicant has been admitted and the necessary financial certification has been provided to the Special Students and Visiting Fellows Office by the student. In order to satisfy US Immigration requirements, international students must demonstrate that they can afford all expenses, including&nbsp;tuition, fees, and living expenses. For additional information about visa regulations please contact the<a href="http://www.hio.harvard.edu/"> Harvard International Office</a>.</p>

<p><strong>How can non-native English speakers demonstrate English proficiency?</strong><br>
Non-native English speakers who attended a university full-time or participated in a year-long program in which English is the language of instruction will have demonstrated English proficiency. If you do not have this experience, you will need to take the Internet-based test (iBT) of the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL), administered by the<a href="http://www.ets.org/toefl"> Educational Testing Service</a> (ETS), and request that ETS send an official score report to the Special Students and Visiting Fellows Office at the Harvard University Graduate School of Arts and Sciences (using Code 3478). Applicants must receive a minimum score of 80; some programs may require a higher score.</p>

<p>Alternatively, you may submit results of the<a href="http://www.ielts.org/test_takers_information.aspx"> International English Language Testing System</a> (IELTS) test (the minimum accepted score is 7), or the<a href="http://pearsonpte.com/"> Pearson Test of English</a> (PTE) results (the minimum accepted score is 70).</p>

<p>If you feel that you meet this prerequisite in another way, please explain why in your application. Please note that if you require a J-1 visa and you have not taken the TOEFL nor have attended an English speaking institution, then you may be required to demonstrate adequate English proficiency by means of an official interview before acceptance into the program.</p>

<p><strong>Is there an International Student Orientation at the beginning of each academic year?</strong><br>
Yes! All international students (including special students and visiting fellows) are invited to attend International Student Orientation during August, where they learn about life at GSAS.</p>

<h2 class="xpandable">General Questions</h2>

<p><strong>If admitted, may I take any of the courses listed in the FAS course catalog?</strong><br>
For the most part, yes! If a course has limited enrollment, full-time undergraduates and other students in Harvard degree programs have first priority. Also, special students and visiting fellows are restricted from participating in a <a href="/restricted-courses">select group of departmental offerings</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Do I need to take the Graduate Record Examination (GRE)?</strong><br>
The GRE is not a required component of the application.</p>

<p><strong>How much is the application fee?</strong><br>
The fee is $105, payable in&nbsp;the online&nbsp;application.</p>

<p><strong>What is an official vs. an unofficial transcript?</strong><br>
A transcript becomes unofficial once the student obtains the document. Official transcripts are typically sent directly to GSAS from your previous institutions; however, official transcripts can come directly from the student if sealed by the institution. An electronic version of your transcript sent to us directly&nbsp;from your institution to GSAS is also acceptable as an official transcript.</p>

<p><strong>What is the best way to contact the Special Students and Visiting Fellows Office?</strong><br>
The office is open Monday through Friday, 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Eastern Time. The best time to contact the Special Students and Visiting Fellows Office is between 9:00 a.m. and 12:00 p.m.</p>

<p><strong>Does Harvard provide health insurance?</strong><br>
Yes! Every registered student is automatically charged and enrolled in the <a href="http://hushp.harvard.edu/">Harvard University Student Health Plan</a> (HUSHP), which the University offers through&nbsp; Blue Cross-Blue Shield of Massachusetts. There is also a required Harvard University Health Services fee paid each term that allows any student to take advantage of Harvard University Health Services walk-in clinic. If students provide documentation establishing that they have comparable insurance that meets pre-determined Commonwealth of Massachusetts and Harvard University Health Services standards, they may be able to <a href="http://hushp.harvard.edu/waive">waive the HUSHP coverage</a> and associated fee.</p>

<p><strong>Do I need immunizations in order to enroll?</strong><br>
Yes! By state law, students enrolling full-time in Massachusetts colleges and universities are required to provide proof of immunization against measles, mumps, rubella, tetanus, diphtheria, Hepatitis B, and meningococcal (or submit a waiver for the meningococcal). Proof of immunizations is compulsory prior to registration. Visit<a href="http://huhs.harvard.edu/health-forms-topics/forms"> Harvard University Health Services</a> for forms and information.</p>

<h2 class="xpandable">Financing Your Study&nbsp;</h2>

<p><strong>Can special students and visiting fellows benefit from Harvard-administered financial aid programs?</strong><br>
Unfortunately Harvard University or GSAS financial aid (including scholarships, work-study, and loans) are not available to non-degree seeking students. Non-degree seeking students who are US citizens or permanent residents are eligible for<a href="https://www.salliemae.com/need-college-happen02/?oref=&amp;opUser=noncookied"> Sallie Mae loans</a>. Non-US citizens with a cosigner who is a US citizen or permanent resident are also eligible. Please note that it may take several weeks to process a loan, and you cannot register until the funds have been applied to your term bill.</p>

<p><strong>Are US special students and visiting fellows eligible for Federal Student Aid?</strong><br>
For US citizens to receive federal aid, they must be enrolled, or plan to enroll, in a degree program of organized instruction that leads to an academic, professional, or vocational degree or certificate. Special students and visiting fellows do not meet this criterion.</p>

<p><strong>Is there anything international students should know about funding their stay?</strong><br>
Yes! Many international visiting fellows applying from abroad are funded by a foundation, government entity, organization, or company, as well as being self-funded. All international visiting fellows must demonstrate that they have sufficient funding before applying. Visa authorization is contingent upon the financial certification of funds to cover tuition and living expenses.</p>

<h2 class="xpandable">About Applying</h2>

<p><strong>I have not attended school for quite a while. What do I do about the academic recommendations?</strong><br>
At least two of your three recommendations should come from teachers or professors who recently taught you in academic subjects. If you have not attended school for a number of years, you may ask employers, colleagues, or other individuals who know you well to write your recommendations. You may consider enrolling in some demanding college courses before applying. Your success in those courses will help demonstrate your academic ability and enable you to achieve the strong academic recommendations that Harvard prefers.</p>

<p><strong>If I gain admission to the program, may I defer my enrollment?</strong><br>
Deferments are not available for this program. If you are unable to attend the semester to which you were admitted then please e-mail the <a href="mailto:special@fas.harvard.edu">Special Students and Visiting Fellows Program</a> office&nbsp;immediately; you will need to create new application account and submit a new application. Because this is considered a re-application, all your previously-submitted documents are attached to the new application and&nbsp;no new documents are required. Please note why you were unable to attend when you reapply. If you were admitted for the full academic year but you now plan to only attend in the spring, please &nbsp;e-mail the&nbsp;<a href="mailto:special@fas.harvard.edu" style="line-height: 24.0001px;">Special Students and Visiting Fellows Program</a>&nbsp;office.</p>

<p><strong>If I am denied admission, may I reapply?</strong><br>
Yes! But you must submit a new application for admission in a subsequent year. You will also need to submit an additional application fee. Please be aware that GSAS will not accept more than three unsuccessful applications from any individual during the course of their academic career.</p>

<p><strong>I&rsquo;m a current non-degree student at Harvard GSAS, but I would like to extend my stay, is that possible?</strong><br>
Possibly.&nbsp;While the program is intended for a short period of study, you may reapply in order to extend your program. Reapplications are considered on a case-by-case basis. You will need to create new application account and submit a new application. When reapplying, you will not need to submit new supporting materials, however, you may wish to update your statement or add transcripts.</p>

<h2 class="xpandable">Space&nbsp;</h2>

<p><strong>Are visiting fellows offered office space in their affiliated department or desk space in the library?</strong><br>
In general, office space is extremely limited, with only a few departments providing offices to visiting fellows. However, you may request a study carrel at Widener Library by submitting a<a href="http://hcl.harvard.edu/info/study_spaces/index.cfm#widener"> Widener Carrel Request Form</a>. Carrels are free of charge and are assigned on a yearly basis.</p>

<p><strong>Are visiting fellows offered laboratory space?</strong><br>
Laboratory space is also limited. Please note any special requirements in your application and discuss whether space is available with your affiliated department.</p>

<h2 class="xpandable">Housing&nbsp;</h2>

<p><strong>Does the Special Students and Visiting Fellows Office assist in locating housing?</strong><br>
Special students and visiting fellows are responsible for finding their own housing. Most visiting fellows seek off-campus, non-Harvard housing. The Harvard-Cambridge area is highly residential and close to campus. Also, much of the city of Boston (including Allston) is accessible by public transportation, as are the surrounding towns of Arlington, Belmont, Brookline, Somerville, and Watertown.<a href="http://www.huhousing.harvard.edu/"> Harvard University Housing</a> also has options to consider.</p>

<p><strong>Do on-campus housing options exist?</strong><br>
Visiting fellows and special students are eligible to apply for limited campus housing at the Cronkhite Graduate Center or in the GSAS residence halls, though married couples and other family members cannot be accommodated. Housing applications may be submitted only after academic admission (non-degree students please ignore the deadline as that applies only to degree students). Visit the<a href="/student-life/housing-dining"> GSAS Office of Residential Life</a> for more information.</p>
</div></div>

  </section>
                            	</div>

<meta name="description" content="PhD students interested in pursuing a secondary field take four or five graduate courses in a discipline, interdisciplinary area, or intellectually coherent subfield. The program offering the secondary field provides an intellectual rationale and outlines the package of courses required." />
